sars-cov-2-virus.What were the previous names of SARS-CoV: previously known as 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) and human coronavirus 2019 (HCoV-19/hCoV-19)
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the genetic relationship between: SARS-CoV-2 is a strain of the severe-acute-respiratory-syndrome-related coronavirus (SARSr-CoV)
sars-cov-2-virus.How does SARS-CoV-2 spread among humans?: spreads through close contact via aerosols and respiratory droplets
sars-cov-2-virus.Why did the WHO suggest the new terminol: The WHO recommended using non-geographical, non-animal-related terms to avoid stigmatization
sars-cov-2-virus.Why was the official name SARS-CoV-2 ado: to adhere to guidelines against using geographical locations, animal species, or groups of people in disease names
sars-cov-2-virus.How was SARS-CoV-2 initially assumed to: initially assumed to occur via respiratory droplets
sars-cov-2-virus.What is another mode of transmission sug: airborne with aerosols transmitting the virus
sars-cov-2-virus.What are the biosafety implications of a: working with viruses in the lab
sars-cov-2-virus.How is SARS-CoV-2 inactivated?: inactivated by soap, which destabilizes the lipid bilayer of the virus
sars-cov-2-virus.When does the pharynx reach peak viral l: around 4 days after infection or in the first week of symptoms. declines after
sars-cov-2-virus.What is RNA shedding?: expulsion and release of viral progeny
sars-cov-2-virus.What occurs after the initial infection: subsequent aspiration-mediated viral seeding into the lungs
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the infection gradient within th: high in proximal pulmonary epithelium to low in distal pulmonary epithelium
sars-cov-2-virus.Where does focal infection occur in the: ciliated cells in the airway and in type 2 pneumocytes in the alveolar regions
sars-cov-2-virus.Which animals are susceptible and permis: cats, ferrets, hamsters, primates, minks, tree shrews, raccoons, dogs, fruit bats, and rabbits
sars-cov-2-virus.Is there certainty about reinfection and: no; uncertainty about reinfection and long-term immunity
sars-cov-2-virus.How long after the initial discharge did: The first reinfection case tested positive again on August 15, 2020, after being discharged on April 15, 2020, with two negative tests
may not eliminate the virus if reinfection is not uncommon
sars-cov-2-virus.Is there a known natural reservoir for S: no, there is no known natural reservoir
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the uncertainty regarding the or: original source and whether pathogenicity emerged before or after the spillover event
sars-cov-2-virus.What is a potential source of the SARS-C: The Huanan Seafood Market, but another explanation is that visitors may have spread it to the market
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the most likely explanation for: human spillover via an intermediate animal host
sars-cov-2-virus.How does the genetic plasticity of SARS-: has a slow viral evolution due to its RNA proofreading capability, despite coronaviruses generally having high genetic plasticity
sars-cov-2-virus.Is the viral mutation rate in vivo highe: tends to be lower than that of influenza
sars-cov-2-virus.Is there evidence supporting the pangoli: no; evidence is against it as pangolin viruses are too distant from SARS-CoV-2, showing only a 92% similarity (low for viruses) and poor binding to the ACE2 receptor w/ few common critical amino acids
sars-cov-2-virus.Which species can SARS-CoV-2 infect?: Humans, mammals (e.g., livestock), and avian species
sars-cov-2-virus.What illnesses can SARS-CoV-2 cause?: Illnesses ranging from the common cold to Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS)
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the position of SARS-CoV-2 among: seventh known coronavirus to infect people
sars-cov-2-virus.What is copy-choice replication?: Gene material switches from one RNA template to another during replication
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the notable characteristic of th: consists nearly entirely of protein-coding sequences
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the distinguishing feature of SA: Incorporation of a polybasic site cleaved by furin (important for virulence)
sars-cov-2-virus.Where is the polybasic site located in t: upstream of R and S, forming the S1/S2 cleavage site (PRRAR↓S) of the spike protein
sars-cov-2-virus.What are the implications of the polybas: aids in zoonotic transfer to humans
sars-cov-2-virus.What announcement did the ICTV make on F: identified 2019-nCoV as a virus of SARSr-CoV
sars-cov-2-virus.What was discovered in October 2020 rega: A possible overlapping gene called ORF3d was discovered
sars-cov-2-virus.What is known about the function of ORF3: function is unknown, but it causes a strong immune response
sars-cov-2-virus.Where was ORF3d identified?: In a coronavirus that infects pangolins
sars-cov-2-virus.How are many variants grouped?: Nextstrain and GISAID divide the variants into different clades
sars-cov-2-virus.How many clades does GISAID divide the v: seven clades: L, O, V, S, G, GH, GR
sars-cov-2-virus.What are the five variants of particular: Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, and Omicron
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the lineage of the Alpha variant: Lineage B.1.1.7; emerged in the UK in September 2020
sars-cov-2-virus.What evidence is there regarding the Alp: evidence of increased transmissibility and virulence
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the lineage of the Beta variant,: Lineage B.1.351; emerged in South Africa in May 2020
sars-cov-2-virus.What evidence is there regarding the Bet: evidence of increased transmissibility and changes to antigenicity
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the lineage of the Gamma variant: Lineage P.1; emerged in Brazil in November 2020
sars-cov-2-virus.What evidence is there regarding the Gam: evidence of increased transmissibility and virulence, with changes to antigenicity
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the lineage of the Delta variant: Lineage P.1.617.2; emerged in India in October 2020
sars-cov-2-virus.What evidence is there regarding the Del: evidence of increased transmissibility and virulence, with changes to antigenicity
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the lineage of the Omicron varia: Lineage B.1.1.529; emerged in Botswana in November 2021
sars-cov-2-virus.What is Cluster 5, and where did it emer: designation used by the Danish Statens Serum Institut for a virus variant in connection with investigations of SARS-CoV-2 infection among mink and humans in the north of Jutland, Denmark; emerged among mink in Denmark
sars-cov-2-virus.What were the consequences of Cluster 5': caused a mink euthanasia campaign and rendered the mink extinct
sars-cov-2-virus.What are the four structural proteins fo: S (spike) protein, E (envelope) protein, M (membrane) protein, N (nucleocapsid) protein
sars-cov-2-virus.How are the S proteins oriented in the m: They are Type I membrane proteins w/ a transmembrane domain oriented on the extracellular side
sars-cov-2-virus.How does the S protein contribute to the: Allows the virus to attach and fuse with the host membrane
sars-cov-2-virus.What are the four types of single-pass t: Type I, Type II, Type III, Type IV
sars-cov-2-virus.How are Type I membrane proteins anchore: With a stop-transfer anchor sequence, targeting the ER lumen at the N termini during synthesis and the extracellular space (ECS) if in mature forms on the membrane
sars-cov-2-virus.How are Type II membrane proteins anchor: With a signal anchor sequence, targeting the ER lumen with C termini domains
sars-cov-2-virus.Where are Type III membrane proteins anc: Anchored with a signal anchor sequence, with N termini targeting the ER lumen
sars-cov-2-virus.Where are alpha helical transmembrane pr: In the inner membrane (prokaryotes) or plasma membrane (eukaryotes), sometimes in the outer membrane (prokaryotes)
sars-cov-2-virus.Where are beta barrel transmembrane prot: In the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, cell walls of Gram-positive bacteria, and outer membranes of mitochondria/chloroplasts
sars-cov-2-virus.What are the two subtypes of Type IV tra: Type IV-A have N termini targeted to the cytosol, while Type IV-B has N termini targeted to the lumen
sars-cov-2-virus.What consequence does the CG mutation bi: Mutation of G and C to A and U; this bias arises to avoid the zinc finger antiviral proteins defense mechanism and reduces the energy needed to unbind the genome
sars-cov-2-virus.What initiates the replication cycle of: Viral particles binding to host surface cellular receptors
sars-cov-2-virus.Besides ACE2, what other cell surface re: Basignin (BSG/Extracellular Matrix Metalloprotease Inducer/Cluster of Differentiation 147)
sars-cov-2-virus.What action does TMPRSS2 perform on the: Cuts open the spike protein and exposes a fusion peptide in S2 subunit
sars-cov-2-virus.How does the virion escape from the endo: When the pH of the endosome drops or when cathepsin, a host cysteine protease, cleaves it
sars-cov-2-virus.What is the effectiveness of drugs in in: Very few drugs are effective against SARS-CoV-2.
sars-cov-2-virus.What reduction in viral titers was obser: A 200-fold reduction in viral titers was observed in the lungs and nose of mice treated with mastinib against SARS-CoV-2.
sars-cov-2-virus.Is mastinib currently approved for treat: No, mastinib is not approved for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2 yet.
sars-cov-2-virus.When did the US grant emergency use auth: The US granted emergency use authorization for nirmatrelvir/ritonavir for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2 in December 2021.
sars-cov-2-virus.Which countries followed the US in grant: The EU, UK, and Canada followed the US in granting emergency use authorization for nirmatrelvir/ritonavir for treatment of SARS-CoV-2.
sars-cov-2-virus.By how much does nirmatrelvir/ritonavir: Nirmatrelvir/ritonavir reduces the risk of hospitalization and death from SARS-CoV-2 by 88%.
sars-cov-2-virus.When did the COVID Moonshot project begi: The COVID Moonshot project began in March 2020 with the goal to develop an unpatented oral antiviral drug against SARS-CoV-2.

hiv-1.What are HIV (human immunodeficiency vir: HIV are species of Lentivirus that infect humans. Over time, they can cause acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
hiv-1.What is the average survival time after: The average survival time is 9-11 years after infection.
hiv-1.How is HIV primarily transmitted sexuall: In most cases, it is sexually transmitted through contact or transfer of blood, pre-ejaculate, semen, and vaginal fluids.
hiv-1.What are the non-sexual transmission rou: Non-sexual transmission includes from infected mother to infant during pregnancy, exposure to infected fluid during childbirth, and through breast milk.
hiv-1.In what forms is HIV present in bodily f: HIV is present as free virus particles and within infected immune cells in bodily fluids.
hiv-1.Under what condition is HIV untransmitta: It is untransmittable if the HIV-positive partner has an undetectable viral load.
hiv-1.Which immune cells does HIV infect?: HIV infects immune cells such as helper T cells, specifically CD4+ T cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.
hiv-1.What are the mechanisms leading to low l: Infection leads to low levels of CD4+ T cells via mechanisms like pyroptosis of abortively infected T cells, apoptosis of uninfected bystander cells, direct viral killing of infected cells, and killing of infected CD4+ T cells by CD8+ cytotoxic lymphocytes that recognize infected cells.
hiv-1.What happens when CD4+ T cell levels dec: When CD4+ T cell levels decline below a critical level, cell-mediated immunity is lost and the body becomes more susceptible to opportunistic infections, leading to AIDS.
hiv-1.What is the taxonomic classification of: HIV is a member of the Lentivirus genus and Retroviridae family.
hiv-1.What are the characteristics of Lentivir: Lentiviruses are responsible for long-duration illnesses with long incubation periods.
hiv-1.How is HIV transmitted?: HIV is transmitted as +ssRNA enveloped viruses (class VI).
hiv-1.What happens upon entry of HIV into a ho: Upon entry, the HIV genome is reverse transcribed into dsDNA by reverse transcriptase.
hiv-1.What happens to the resulting viral DNA?: The resulting viral DNA is imported into the nucleus and integrated into cellular DNA by a virally encoded integrase and host cofactors.
hiv-1.What are the two possible outcomes after: Once integrated, the virus can become latent and avoid detection by the immune system, remaining dormant for up to 10 years after primary infection (asymptomatic period). Alternatively, the viral DNA can be transcribed to produce new RNA genomes and viral proteins, leading to viral replication and release.
hiv-1.What are the alternative names for HIV-1: HIV-1 was initially discovered and is termed both lymphadenopathy-associated virus (LAV) and human T-lymphotropic virus 3 (HTLV-III).
hiv-1.How does HIV-1 compare to HIV-2 in terms: HIV-1 is more virulent and infective than HIV-2.
hiv-1.Where is HIV-2 predominantly found?: HIV-2 has poor capacity for transmission and is confined primarily to West Africa.
hiv-1.What is the size and shape of the HIV vi: HIV is roughly spherical with a diameter of 120 nm.
hiv-1.What is the composition of the HIV genom: The HIV genome consists of two copies of +ssRNA that code for nine genes.
hiv-1.What is the composition of the conical c: The capsid is composed of 2000 copies of the viral p24 protein.
hiv-1.How is the viral RNA packaged within the: The viral RNA is tightly bound to nucleocapsid proteins p7 and enzymes for virion development.
hiv-1.What are the enzymes present within the: The enzymes include reverse transcriptase, proteases, ribonuclease, and integrase.
hiv-1.What is the function of the matrix prote: The matrix protein p17 surrounds the capsid to ensure integrity.
hiv-1.Describe the composition of the viral en: The viral envelope is composed of a host lipid bilayer from budding and contains host proteins along with a few copies of the HIV envelope protein. It consists of a cap made from glycoprotein (gp) 120 and a stem made of three gp41 molecules that anchor the structure into the envelope.
hiv-1.What is the significance of the envelope: The envelope protein allows for attachment and fusion and is the only protein on the viral surface, making it a major target for HIV vaccine efforts.
hiv-1.What is the role of glycans in the HIV e: Glycans constitute over 50% of the mass of the trimeric envelope and shield the underlying viral protein from neutralization by antibodies. They are so densely packed that they prevent normal glycan maturation during biogenesis in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and Golgi. This density and processing mean that almost all broadly neutralizing antibodies against HIV target or cope with envelope glycans.
hiv-1.How was the structure of the viral spike: The viral spike structure was determined by X-ray crystallography and CryoEM.
hiv-1.What enabled the determination of the vi: The stable recombinant form of the viral spike was developed by introducing an intersubunit disulfide bond and an isoleucine to proline mutation (radical replacement) in the gp41 protein, making it possible for X-ray crystallography and CryoEM to be applied.
hiv-1.What are SOSIP trimers, and why are they: SOSIP trimers are recombinant trimeric viral spikes that reproduce the antigenic properties of the native spike while also displaying the same degree of immature glycans as the native virus. They are significant because they are good vaccine candidates, showing fewer non-neutralizing epitopes compared to recombinant monomeric gp120, which can suppress the immune response to target epitopes.
hiv-1.What are the structural landmarks of the: The HIV genome has at least seven structural landmarks: LTR (long terminal repeat), TAR (trans-activation response element), the binding site for Tat proteins, RRE (Rev response element), PE (Psi elements), SLIP (TTTTTT slippery site + stem loop), CRS (Cis-acting repressive sequences), and INS (inhibitory/instability RNA sequences).
hiv-1.What is the function of the RRE element: The RRE element, encoded within env, is necessary for Rev function.
hiv-1.What is the function of the PE (Psi elem: The PE consists of 4 stem loops with overlap of the Gag start codon and is recognized by the cysteine histidine box. It is involved in regulating viral replication.
hiv-1.What is the role of the SLIP element in: The SLIP element regulates -1 frameshift out of Gag reading frame into Pol reading frame during translation.
hiv-1.What is the function of CRS (Cis-acting: CRS inhibits structural protein expression in the absence of Rev, thus regulating viral gene expression.
hiv-1.What is the role of INS (inhibitory/inst: INS elements can act independently to inhibit expression posttranscriptionally. Mutation of RNA elements leads to INS inactivation and upregulation of gene expression.
hiv-1.How many genes does the HIV genome typic: The HIV genome typically contains at least nine genes, sometimes ten.
hiv-1.What does the gag gene encode?: The gag gene encodes the capsid proteins, also known as group-specific antigens (Gag).
hiv-1.What are the products of the gag gene pr: The precursor protein, p55, is myristoylated and processed into p17 (matrix), p24 (capsid), p7 (nucleocapsid), and p6. These proteins associate with the plasma membrane for virus assembly. The Gag precursor is called assemblin.
hiv-1.What does the pol gene encode, and how a: The pol gene encodes the viral protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase. These enzymes are produced as a Gag-Pol precursor polyprotein, which is cleaved to release the individual enzymes. The precursor is made by frameshifting near the 3’ end of gag.
hiv-1.What does the env gene encode, and what: The env gene encodes the envelope glycoproteins gp120 and gp41. These proteins are produced as a gp160 precursor, which gives rise to a noncovalent complex of gp120 and gp41.
hiv-1.How are mature gp120-gp41 complexes arra: Mature gp120-gp41 complexes are bound by noncovalent interactions and associated as a trimer on the cell surface.
hiv-1.What is the function of gp120, and what: Gp120 contains the binding site for CD4 and the seven chemokine receptors that act as coreceptors for HIV-1. It is a significant target for HIV vaccine efforts.
hiv-1.What is the function of the tat gene?: The tat gene encodes the transactivator of gene expression, one of the two essential regulatory factors for HIV gene expression.
hiv-1.What are the two exons of Tat, and where: Tat-1 exon (minor) consists of 72 amino acids (AAs), and Tat-2 exon (major) consists of 86 AAs. They are localized in the nucleolus/nucleus.
hiv-1.How does Tat function in gene expression: Tat binds to the TAR RNA element and activates initiation and elongation by the long terminal repeat (LTR) promoter. It prevents premature termination by binding to the 5’ LTR AATAAA polyadenylation signal.
hiv-1.What is unique about Tat in terms of tra: Tat is the first eukaryotic transcription factor to interact with RNA rather than DNA and may be similar to prokaryotic antitermination factors.
hiv-1.What is the function of the rev gene?: The rev gene encodes the second transactivator of gene expression. It is a 19-kD phosphoprotein localized in the nucleolus/nucleus.
hiv-1.What does Rev do in terms of mRNA proces: Rev binds to the Rev response element (RRE) and promotes the nuclear export, stabilization, and utilization of viral mRNAs containing RRE.
hiv-1.What is the significance of the nef gene: The nef gene encodes a multifunctional myristoylated protein produced by the ORF at the 3’ end of lentiviruses. It is the first HIV protein produced in infected cells and is the most immunogenic of accessory proteins.
hiv-1.What are some functions of Nef?: Nef downregulates CD4 and MHC class I molecules, interacts with components of host cell signal transduction and clathrin-dependent protein sorting, and contains PxxP motifs that bind to SH3 domains of Src kinases required for enhanced growth of HIV.
hiv-1.What is the function of the vif gene?: The vif gene promotes infectivity but not virion production.
hiv-1.What are the characteristics of the vif: The vif protein is 23 kD in size and is found in almost all lentiviruses. It exists in cytoplasmic forms, including soluble cytosolic and membrane-associated forms. The membrane-associated form is peripheral and tightly associated with the cytoplasmic side.
hiv-1.What is the role of Vif in preventing AP: Vif prevents the action of cellular APOBEC-3G while deaminating DNA:RNA heteroduplexes in the cytoplasm.
hiv-1.What is the function of the vpr gene?: The vpr gene is incorporated into the virion and interacts with p6 Gag of the Pr55 Gag precursor. It is primarily localized to the nucleus.
hiv-1.What are some proposed functions of the: Proposed functions of Vpr include targeting nuclear import of preintegration complexes, inducing cell growth arrest, transactivating cellular genes, and inducing cellular differentiation.
hiv-1.What is unique about the vpu gene?: The vpu gene is unique to HIV-1 and is not found in HIV-2 or similar SIVs.
hiv-1.What are some characteristics of the vpu: The vpu protein is an 81 AA type I integral membrane protein. It functions to degrade CD4 in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and enhance virion release from infected cells.
hiv-1.What is the involvement of Vpu in cellul: Vpu likely has an N-terminal hydrophobic membrane anchor and a hydrophilic moiety. It is phosphorylated by casein kinase II at Ser52 and Ser56 and is involved in Env maturation.
hiv-1.What is the function of the vpx gene?: The vpx gene is found in HIV-2 and similar SIVs and is a 12 kD accessory gene homologous to vpr.
hiv-1.What are some characteristics of the vpx: Viruses containing vpx also contain vpr, and vpx is incorporated into virions at levels similar to Gag through interactions with Gag p6.
hiv-1.What is the significance of Vpx for vira: Vpx is necessary for efficient replication of SIV-SMM in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs).
hiv-1.What is the tev gene?: The tev gene involves the fusion of tat, env, and rev, encoding 19 proteins.
hiv-1.How many proteins in total do all the HI: All the HIV genes together encode 19 proteins.
hiv-1.What is the role of Gag, Pol, and Env ge: Gag, Pol, and Env genes contain information necessary for making structural particles for new virions.
hiv-1.What is the function of the gp160 protei: The gp160 protein encoded by the env gene is cleaved by a protease into gp120 and gp41, which are essential for viral entry and fusion.
hiv-1.What is the function of the regulatory g: The other 6 genes in HIV are regulatory and control HIV’s ability to infect cells, produce new copies, or cause disease.
hiv-1.What are the two Tat proteins, and what: The two Tat proteins, p16 and p14, are transcriptional activators for the LTR promoter by binding to the TAR RNA element.
hiv-1.What is the role of the TAR RNA element,: The TAR RNA element can be processed into miRNAs that regulate ERCC1 and IER3 for apoptosis.
hiv-1.What is the function of the Rev protein,: The Rev (p19) protein shuttles RNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm by binding to the RRE RNA element.
hiv-1.What is the function of the Vif protein,: The Vif (p23) protein prevents the action of APOBEC3G, which deaminates C to U in ssDNA and/or interferes with reverse transcription (RT).
hiv-1.What is the function of the Vpr protein,: The Vpr (p14) protein arrests cell division at the G2/M phase, aiding in viral replication.
hiv-1.What are the functions of the Nef protei: The Nef (p27) protein downregulates CD4 and MHC class I and class II molecules. Additionally, Nef interacts with SH3 domains.
hiv-1.What is the function of the Vpu protein?: The Vpu (p16) protein helps release new virus particles from infected cells.
hiv-1.What are the roles of the LTR regions at: The LTR regions act as switches to control the production of new viruses, which can be triggered by either HIV or the host.
hiv-1.What is the function of the Psi element,: The Psi element helps with genome packaging and is recognized by Gag and Rev proteins.
hiv-1.What is the function of the SLIP element: The SLIP element helps frameshift the gag-pol reading frame to make functional pol proteins.
hiv-1.What does tropism refer to in the contex: Tropism refers to the cell types that a virus infects.
hiv-1.Which cell types does HIV infect?: HIV infects CD4+ T cells, macrophages, and microglial cells.
hiv-1.What is the mechanism of entry for HIV i: Entry into macrophages and CD4+ T cells is mediated by the interaction of gp120 with the CD4 molecule on the target cell membrane, as well as chemokine coreceptors.
hiv-1.What are the characteristics of macropha: M-tropic strains of HIV-1, also known as non-syncytia-inducing strains (NSI/R5 viruses), use the beta-chemokine receptor CCR5 for entry and can replicate in both macrophages and CD4+ T cells.
hiv-1.Which chemokine receptor is used by all: All primary HIV-1 isolates, regardless of subtype, use the CCR5 coreceptor.
hiv-1.What are the characteristics of T-tropic: T-tropic strains of HIV-1, also called syncytia-inducing strains (SI/X4 viruses), replicate in primary CD4+ T cells and macrophages and use the alpha-chemokine receptor CXCR4 for entry.
hiv-1.What are dual-tropic strains of HIV-1, a: Dual-tropic strains of HIV-1 can use both CCR5 and CXCR4 for entry, making them transitional.
hiv-1.What is the significance of the CCR5-del: People with the CCR5-delta32 mutation are resistant to R5 strains of HIV because the virus cannot bind to the CCR5 coreceptor.
hiv-1.What is the major mode of transmission o: Sexual intercourse is the major mode of transmission, and both X4 and R5 strains are present in seminal fluid.
hiv-1.What is the role of viral adaptation to: Viral adaptation to use CXCR4 instead of CCR5 is a key step in the progression to AIDS.
hiv-1.What percentage of AIDS patients have SI: 40-50% of AIDS patients have SI viruses (X4 phenotype), which replicate more aggressively and lead to quicker depletion of T cells.
hiv-1.What are some characteristics of HIV-2 i: HIV-2 is much less pathogenic and is restricted to West Africa. It contains accessory genes and exhibits a promiscuous pattern of coreceptor usage (CD4-independence).
hiv-1.What are the initial steps of the entry: The initial steps of entry involve the attachment of the virion to receptors on target cells, followed by fusion of the viral envelope with the cell membrane and release of the capsid into the cell.
hiv-1.What is the role of the trimeric envelop: The trimeric envelope complex interacts with both CD4 and a chemokine coreceptor (CCR5/CXCR4/others) to initiate entry into the target cell.
hiv-1.How does gp120 facilitate efficient tran: Gp120 binds to integrin alpha4beta7 and activates LFA-1, facilitating the formation of virological synapses for efficient transmission of HIV-1.
hiv-1.What is the first step in the fusion pro: The first step is the high-affinity attachment of the CD4 binding domains of gp120 to CD4 on the target cell surface.
hiv-1.How does the envelope complex change str: The envelope complex changes structure to expose the chemokine receptor binding domains of gp120, allowing interaction with the target chemokine receptor.
hiv-1.What role does the N-terminal fusion pep: The N-terminal fusion peptide (gp41) penetrates the cell membrane, facilitating fusion between the viral envelope and the cell membrane.
hiv-1.What happens after the fusion of the vir: After fusion, repeat sequences in gp41, HR1, and HR2 interact, causing the collapse of the extracellular portion of gp41 into a hairpin shape. This brings the membranes close together and facilitates fusion, allowing the capsid to enter the cell.
hiv-1.What occurs after RNA and enzymes are in: After binding, RNA and enzymes (reverse transcriptase, integrase, ribonuclease, protease) are injected into the cell.
hiv-1.What happens to the single-stranded RNA: During microtubule-based transport to the nucleus, the single-stranded RNA genome is transcribed into double-stranded DNA, which integrates into the host chromosome.
hiv-1.How can HIV infect dendritic cells (DCs): HIV can infect DCs through the CD4-CCR5 route and also by using mannose-specific C-type lectin receptors such as DC-SIGN.
hiv-1.What role do dendritic cells (DCs) play: DCs are one of the first cells encountered during sexual transmission and can help transmit HIV to T cells when HIV is captured in the mucosa by DCs.
hiv-1.What is the role of FEZ-1 in preventing: The presence of FEZ-1, particularly in neurons, prevents HIV infection.
hiv-1.What is an alternative route of HIV entr: HIV-1 entry was thought to occur exclusively at the plasma membrane, but there has also been evidence of productive infection by pH-independent clathrin-mediated endocytosis, which may constitute a route of productive entry.
hiv-1.What is the role of reverse transcriptas: Reverse transcriptase liberates +ssRNA from viral proteins and copies it into a cDNA molecule. RT also degrades viral RNA while synthesizing cDNA and creates sense DNA from antisense cDNA.
hiv-1.What are the consequences of reverse tra: Reverse transcription being error-prone may result in drug resistance or enable the virus to evade the immune system.
hiv-1.What is the function of integrase in HIV: Integration into the host genome is carried out by integrase. Integrated DNA may lie dormant in the latent stage.
hiv-1.What transcription factor is essential f: The most important transcription factor for active virus production is NF-kappaB. NF-kappaB is upregulated when T cells are activated, as these cells are actively fighting infection.
hiv-1.How is selectivity in packaging of the v: Selectivity in packaging is explained by the dimeric conformer of genomic RNA (gRNA), characterized by a tandem three-way junction within the gRNA monomer. This allows for specific binding of NC protein and assembly of new viral particles.
hiv-1.What role does RNA splicing play in HIV: RNA splicing produces mRNAs shorter than the full-length genome and determines which protein-coding sequences are translated.
hiv-1.What is the function of the Rev protein: Rev protein binds to full-length unspliced RNA copies in the nucleus and allows for their export from the nucleus.
hiv-1.How do HIV-1 and HIV-2 differ in their R: HIV-1 binds to any appropriate RNA, while HIV-2 preferentially binds to mRNA used to create the Gag protein itself.
hiv-1.How many RNA genomes are encapsidated pe: Two RNA genomes are encapsidated per HIV-1 particle.
hiv-1.When does recombination occur during HIV: Recombination occurs when the +ssRNA genomes are reverse transcribed into DNA.
hiv-1.What is copy choice recombination?: Copy choice recombination occurs when nascent DNA switches multiple times between the two RNA copies during reverse transcription.
hiv-1.How many recombination events may occur: Anywhere from 2-20 recombination events per genome may occur at each replication cycle, rapidly shuffling genetic information.
hiv-1.What are the consequences of viral recom: Viral recombination produces genetic variation that contributes to the evolution of antiretroviral therapy resistance and may also contribute to overcoming immune defenses of the host.
hiv-1.How does template switching by reverse t: Template switching acts as a repair process to deal with breaks in the ssRNA genome, creating an undamaged copy of the genome from two damaged copies.
hiv-1.What is the role of recombination in HIV: Recombination may be an adaptation for repair and variation, with the benefit of repair occurring at each replication cycle, regardless of genetic differences between the genomes.
hiv-1.What factors make the HIV genome vulnera: HIV-1 inflammation causes chronic inflammation and production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), making the genome vulnerable to oxidative damage.
hiv-1.Why is successful infection dependent on: Successful infection depends on overcoming host defense strategies, so recombination may be an adaptation for repair and variation to achieve successful infection.
hiv-1.Where does HIV assembly begin?: HIV assembly begins at the plasma membrane of the host cell.
hiv-1.Describe the processing of Env (gp160) d: Env (gp160) is transported from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the Golgi, where it is cleaved by furin, resulting in the formation of gp41 and gp120. These proteins are then transported to the plasma membrane.
hiv-1.How do Gp41 and Gag proteins contribute: Gp41 anchors gp120 to the plasma membrane, while Gag (p55) and Gag-Pol (p160) polyproteins associate with the inner surface of the plasma membrane along with the genomic RNA as the virion buds from the host membrane.
hiv-1.What is the status of the virion after b: The budded virion is still immature since the gag polyproteins need to be cleaved into the matrix, capsid, and nucleocapsid proteins.
hiv-1.How is the cleavage of gag polyproteins: The cleavage of gag polyproteins is mediated by the viral protease, although this process is inhibited by antiretroviral protease inhibitors.
hiv-1.What happens after the cleavage of gag p: After cleavage, the structural components assemble to produce a mature HIV virion, which is then ready for further infection.
hiv-1.What is the classic process of HIV infec: The classic process of HIV infection spread is cell-free spread, where virus particles bud from infected T cells, enter the blood or extracellular fluid, and infect another cell by chance encounter. This is distinguished from cell-to-cell spread.
hiv-1.Describe the process of cell-to-cell spr: Cell-to-cell spread of HIV can occur via two pathways: (1) Infected T cells can transmit the virus directly to target T cells via a virological synapse, or (2) antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages or dendritic cells can transmit HIV to T cells through productive infection or transfer of virions in trans.
hiv-1.What makes cell-to-cell spread of HIV mo: Cell-to-cell spread of HIV is more efficient due to several factors, including polarized virus budding towards the site of cell-to-cell contact, close apposition of cells minimizing fluid-phase diffusion of virions, and clustering of HIV entry receptors on target cells towards the contact zone.
hiv-1.Where is cell-to-cell spread particularl: Cell-to-cell spread of HIV is particularly important in lymphoid tissues with densely packed CD4+ T cells.
hiv-1.How do intravital imaging studies suppor: Intravital imaging studies have supported the concept of the HIV virological synapse by visualizing the direct transmission of HIV from infected cells to target cells in living tissues.
hiv-1.Why do many dissemination mechanisms for: Many dissemination mechanisms for HIV contribute to ongoing replication even in the presence of antiretroviral therapies, allowing the virus to persist and evade treatment.
hiv-1.What factors contribute to the high gene: The high genetic variability of HIV is attributed to its fast replication cycle, generating approximately 10^10 virions per day, a high mutation rate (~3*10^-5 nucleotide changes per cycle), and the recombinogenic properties of the reverse transcriptase enzyme (RT).
hiv-1.How does simultaneous infection with two: Simultaneous infection with two different HIV strains can lead to the generation of recombinant viral genomes. When progeny genomes contain RNA from two different strains, recombination events can occur during reverse transcription, contributing to increased genetic diversity.
hiv-1.What is the significance of recombinatio: Recombination in HIV leads to the rapid shuffling of genetic information between different strains. This process allows HIV to generate genetic diversity, which is crucial for its adaptation, evolution, and the development of drug resistance.
hiv-1.Describe the variability of Simian Immun: SIV exhibits variability across different natural hosts. For example, SIV of African green monkey (SIVagm) and sooty mangabey (SIVsmm) have a long evolutionary history and typically do not cause severe disease in their natural hosts. However, when these strains infect species not adapted to SIV, such as rhesus or cynomolgus macaques, they can lead to the development of AIDS and genetic diversity.
hiv-1.How does HIV-1 subtype M differ from sub: HIV-1 is classified into three groups based on differences in the env region: M, N, and O. Group M is the most prevalent and has eight subtypes that are geographically distinct. Subtypes A and D are mainly found in Africa, while subtype B is predominantly found in North America and Europe. Subtype C is mainly found in Africa and Asia. Coinfection with distinct subtypes can give rise to circulating recombinant forms (CRFs).
hiv-1.What is the focus of most HIV-1 research: Most HIV-1 research is focused on subtype B, which is predominantly found in North America and Europe. However, other subtypes and circulating recombinant forms (CRFs) also contribute to the global diversity of HIV-1 and are important areas of study.
hiv-1.What is the proposed significance of the: The existence of the P group of HIV has been hypothesized based on an isolation in 2009 derived from gorilla SIV (SIVgor) in western lowland gorillas in 2006. Further research is needed to understand the significance and characteristics of this group.
hiv-1.What is the relationship between HIV-2 a: HIV-2's closest relative is SIVsm, which is found in sooty mangabees. The genetic sequence of HIV-2 is only partially homologous to HIV-1 and more closely resembles SIVsm.
hiv-1.How does recombination contribute to the: Recombination in HIV occurs when nascent DNA switches multiple times between two RNA copies during reverse transcription. This process, known as copy-choice recombination, leads to the rapid shuffling of genetic information between different strains, contributing to increased genetic diversity.
hiv-1.What is the prevalence of HIV-positive i: The prevalence of HIV-positive individuals who are unaware of their infection is less than 1%, although this proportion may be even lower in rural populations.
hiv-1.Why is routine screening of donor blood: Routine screening of donor blood and blood products is important because donors may be unaware of their HIV infection status. Screening helps to prevent the transmission of HIV through blood transfusions and ensures the safety of medical procedures and research involving blood products.
hiv-1.What is the initial testing method for H: The initial testing method for HIV-1 diagnosis is enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), which is used to detect antibodies to HIV-1 in the patient's blood.
hiv-1.How are specimens with nonreactive resul: Specimens with nonreactive results from the initial ELISA test are considered HIV-negative, unless there has been a new exposure to a potential HIV-positive partner.
hiv-1.What is the next step if a specimen show: If a specimen shows a reactive result on the ELISA test, it is retested. If the result of either duplicate test is reactive, the specimen is reported as repeatedly reactive and undergoes confirmatory testing with a more specific supplemental test.
hiv-1.What are examples of supplemental tests: Examples of supplemental tests used for confirmatory testing of HIV include polymerase chain reaction (PCR), Western blot, and indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA).
hiv-1.How is a specimen confirmed as HIV-posit: Specimens are confirmed as HIV-positive if they are repeatedly reactive by ELISA and positive by supplemental tests such as IFA, PCR, or Western blot.
hiv-1.What is the significance of an indetermi: An indeterminate Western blot result may occur when a specimen is repeatedly reactive by ELISA but does not provide a clear positive result on Western blot. This may be due to an incomplete antibody response or nonspecific reactions, particularly in uninfected individuals.
hiv-1.Which supplemental test can be used to c: Indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) can be used to confirm infection in ambiguous cases, but it is not widely used in HIV diagnosis.
hiv-1.What should be done for individuals with: For individuals with indeterminate Western blot results, a second specimen should be collected >1 month later and retested.
hiv-1.What is the purpose of nucleic acid test: Nucleic acid testing for viral RNA/proviral DNA amplification, although less commonly available, can help in the diagnosis of HIV, particularly in cases where other tests yield inconclusive results.
hiv-1.What should be done if a tested specimen: If a tested specimen yields inconclusive results due to low quantity, another specimen should be collected and tested.
hiv-1.How accurate is modern HIV testing, and: Modern HIV testing is very accurate, with screening tests correct >99% of the time. The window period is taken into consideration to ensure accurate diagnosis.
hiv-1.What is the false-positive rate in a two: In low-risk populations, the false-positive rate in a two-step testing protocol is approximately 1 in 250,000.
hiv-1.What is the recommended testing schedule: Testing post-exposure is recommended immediately, at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months after exposure to HIV.
hiv-1.What is the CDC's recommendation for HIV: The CDC recommends that HIV testing must start with an immunoassay combination test for HIV-1 and HIV-2 antibodies and p24 antigen. A positive result requires follow-up with an HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay.
hiv-1.What are the four possible scenarios bas: The four possible scenarios based on the results of HIV testing are: HIV-1 positive and HIV-2 negative, HIV-1 negative and HIV-2 positive, HIV-1 positive and HIV-2 positive, and HIV-1 negative or indeterminate and HIV-2 negative. A nucleic acid test needs to be carried out in the last scenario to detect acute infection of HIV-1 or its absence.
hiv-1.What are the primary areas of research r: The primary areas of research related to HIV/AIDS include preventing, treating, and curing the disease, as well as understanding the fundamental nature of HIV and AIDS as the disease caused by HIV.
hiv-1.What are some examples of research in be: Research in behavioral health interventions related to HIV/AIDS includes studies on sex education programs aimed at reducing transmission rates.
hiv-1.What types of drug development research: Drug development research related to HIV/AIDS includes the development of microbicides for sexually transmitted diseases, HIV vaccines, and antiretroviral drugs.
hiv-1.What is the focus of medical research on: Medical research on pre-exposure prophylaxis focuses on strategies to prevent HIV infection in individuals who are at high risk of exposure.
hiv-1.What does research on post-exposure prop: Research on post-exposure prophylaxis aims to develop effective treatment protocols for individuals who have been exposed to HIV to prevent the establishment of infection.
hiv-1.What is the primary approach to managing: The primary approach to managing HIV infection is through the use of multiple antiretroviral drugs.
hiv-1.What is the goal of highly active antire: The goal of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is to decrease the total viral burden, maintain immune function, and prevent opportunistic infections.
hiv-1.How many classes of drugs are typically: Six classes of drugs are typically used in combination for HIV treatment.
hiv-1.How are antiretroviral (ARV) drugs class: Antiretroviral (ARV) drugs are broadly classified based on the phase of the retrovirus life-cycle they inhibit.
hiv-1.What are some typical combinations of an: Typical combinations of antiretroviral drugs used in HIV treatment include two nucleoside RT inhibitors (NRTI) as a backbone, along with one non-nucleoside RT inhibitor (NNRTI), protease inhibitor (PI), or integrase inhibitors (or integrase nuclear strand transfer inhibitors/INSTIs) as a base.
hiv-1.What are entry inhibitors in the context: Entry inhibitors, also called fusion inhibitors, interfere with the binding, fusion, and entry of HIV-1 by blocking specific targets.
hiv-1.Name three examples of entry inhibitors: Three examples of entry inhibitors used in HIV treatment are maraviroc (targets CCR5), enfuvirtide (prevents fusion), and ibalizumab (targets both CCR5 and CXCR4 tropic HIV).
hiv-1.What caution must be exercised when usin: Caution must be used when using maraviroc in HIV treatment because there may be a shift in tropism by using CXCR5.
hiv-1.How does enfuvirtide prevent fusion of H: Enfuvirtide is a peptide that must be injected and interacts with the N-terminal heptad repeat of gp41 of HIV to form an inactive hetero six-helix bundle, thus preventing fusion.
hiv-1.What resistance mechanism may individual: Individuals with a mutation in CCR5 delta may have a means of resistance or slower progression of HIV.
hiv-1.How can resistance to enfuvirtide be ove: Resistance to enfuvirtide can be overcome if an HIV variant that targets CXCR4 becomes dominant.
hiv-1.What is the mechanism of action of nucle: NRTI/NtRTI act as chain terminators by inhibiting reverse transcriptase (RT) and lacking a 3’ OH group for subsequent nucleoside incorporation, thereby competitively inhibiting RT.
hiv-1.Name four examples of NRTIs used in HIV: Examples of NRTIs used in HIV treatment include zidovudine, abacavir, lamivudine, and emtricitabine.
hiv-1.How do non-nucleoside reverse transcript: NNRTIs inhibit RT by binding to an allosteric site, acting as noncompetitive inhibitors and affecting the handling of nucleotides by binding near the active site.
hiv-1.What are the first and second generation: First-generation NNRTIs include nevirapine and efavirenz, while second-generation NNRTIs include etravirine and rilpivirine.
hiv-1.Which class of HIV drugs is HIV-2 resist: HIV-2 is resistant to non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs).
hiv-1.How do integrase inhibitors such as ralt: Integrase inhibitors like raltegravir compete for substrate with two Mg2+ ions at the metal binding site of integrase, thus inhibiting its function.
hiv-1.Name five examples of protease inhibitor: Examples of protease inhibitors used in HIV treatment include lopinavir, indinavir, nelfinavir, amprenavir, and ritonavir.
hiv-1.Which protease inhibitors are recommende: Darunavir and atazanavir are recommended for first-line therapy in HIV treatment.
hiv-1.What is the mechanism of action of matur: Maturation inhibitors bind to gag proteins, preventing the cleavage of gag and gag/pol precursors, leading to the production of defective and mostly noninfectious virions.
hiv-1.Why was the development of bevirimat and: The development of bevirimat and vivecon, maturation inhibitors, was halted in 2010 due to issues with high resistance and the development of second-generation drugs that are effective against otherwise resistant HIV variants.
hiv-1.What is the rationale behind combination: Combination therapy is used to suppress viral replication even if a mutation that conveys resistance to one drug arises, as the others continue to suppress reproduction of that mutation.
hiv-1.How many drugs are typically included in: Combination therapy for HIV typically consists of three drugs from more than two classes, often referred to as a 'triple cocktail'.
hiv-1.What are the limitations of combination: Combinations are limited to positive and negative synergies, which limits the useful combinations that can be created.
hiv-1.What is the concept of Undetectable=Untr: U=U refers to the fact that transmission doesn’t occur through sex when an HIV-positive individual has a consistent undetectable viral load due to antiretroviral treatment, meaning they cannot transmit the virus to others.
hiv-1.Which studies have demonstrated the conc: Studies demonstrating U=U include Opposites Attract, PARTNER 1, PARTNER 2, and HPTN052.
hiv-1.What is the impact of genital herpes (HS: Genital herpes (HSV-2) reactivation leads to an increase in CCR-5 enriched CD4+ cells and inflammatory dendritic cells in the submucosa of genital skin, which explains the 2-3 fold increase in HIV acquisition in individuals with genital herpes.
hiv-1.Does antiviral medication (acyclovir) fo: No, antiviral medication (acyclovir) for genital herpes does not reduce subclinical post-reactivation inflammation and does not confer a reduced risk of HIV acquisition.

influenza-a-virus.What is Influenza A also known as?: Influenza A is also known as IAV.
influenza-a-virus.What type of illness does Influenza A ca: Influenza A causes the flu in birds and some mammals, including humans.
influenza-a-virus.What type of virus is Influenza A?: Influenza A is an RNA virus.
influenza-a-virus.Where are the subtypes of Influenza A ty: The subtypes of Influenza A are typically isolated from wild birds.
influenza-a-virus.How is Influenza A occasionally transmit: Influenza A is occasionally transmitted from wild birds to domestic birds and may cause severe outbreaks.
influenza-a-virus.What is notable about the viral genome o: The viral genome of Influenza A is segmented.
influenza-a-virus.What was developed in response to Influe: A filtered and purified influenza A vaccine has been developed, and many countries have stockpiled it in the event of an avian influenza pandemic.
influenza-a-virus.What significant discovery was made abou: In 2011, researchers found an antibody effective against all types of Influenza A virus.
influenza-a-virus.What is the genus and family of Influenz: Influenza A belongs to the genus Alphainfluenzavirus of the family Orthomyxoviridae.
influenza-a-virus.How is Influenza A classified based on s: Influenza A is classified based on surface proteins, also known as serotypes.
influenza-a-virus.How is Influenza A classified based on b: Influenza A is classified based on behavior, particularly the host animal.
influenza-a-virus.What are the two proteins found on the s: Hemagglutinin (H/HA) and Neuraminidase (N/NA) are the two proteins found on the surface of the Influenza A envelope.
influenza-a-virus.What is the function of Hemagglutinin (H: Hemagglutinin (HA) allows the virus to bind to sialic acid receptors on the host cell surface, facilitating viral entry into the cell.
influenza-a-virus.Why is Hemagglutinin (HA) named as such?: Hemagglutinin (HA) is named based on its ability to cause red blood cells to agglutinate, although this phenomenon is not physiologically relevant to the virus in vivo.
influenza-a-virus.What is the function of Neuraminidase (N: Neuraminidase (NA) cleaves glycosidic bonds of sialic acid receptors on the host cell surface, facilitating the release of newly formed virus particles from the infected cell.
influenza-a-virus.How do differences in Hemagglutinin (HA): Differences in Hemagglutinin (HA) and Neuraminidase (NA) proteins contribute to variations in Influenza A subtypes. Based on how H and N react with antisera, scientists have defined 18 types of H and 11 types of N, which determine the subtype of the virus.
influenza-a-virus.How are Influenza A subtypes designated: Influenza A subtypes are designated based on the types of Hemagglutinin (H) and Neuraminidase (N) proteins they possess. For example, H5N1 designates an Influenza A subtype with Type 5 Hemagglutinin and Type 1 Neuraminidase.
influenza-a-virus.What method is commonly used to determin: PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is commonly used to determine the serotype of Influenza A viruses.
influenza-a-virus.Why is it important to subtype Influenza: Subtyping Influenza A viruses is important for surveillance, vaccine development, and understanding the potential for antigenic drift or shift, which can affect the effectiveness of vaccines and the severity of flu seasons.
influenza-a-virus.What are the implications of variations: Variations within Influenza A subtypes can lead to differences in the virus's behavior, including its transmission, pathogenicity, and ability to cause outbreaks or pandemics.
influenza-a-virus.How are Influenza A variants typically n: Influenza A variants are typically named according to the strain's endemic host or the host for which it is adapted.
influenza-a-virus.What are the main variants of Influenza: The main variants of Influenza A include bird flu, human flu, swine influenza, equine influenza, canine influenza, and bat influenza.
influenza-a-virus.How have variants of Influenza A sometim: Variants of Influenza A have sometimes been named based on their deadliness in poultry. For example, Low Pathogenic Avian Influenza (LPAI) and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI), also known as deadly flu or death flu.
influenza-a-virus.What distinguishes Low Pathogenic Avian: Low Pathogenic Avian Influenza (LPAI) is characterized by milder symptoms and lower mortality rates in birds, whereas Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) is associated with severe illness and high mortality rates among infected birds.
influenza-a-virus.What information does the Influenza viru: The Influenza virus nomenclature typically includes the serotype, time, place of collection, and sequence number.
influenza-a-virus.Can subtyping and host range alone uniqu: No, subtyping and host range alone are insufficient to uniquely identify an Influenza A virus.
influenza-a-virus.How is an Influenza A virus named accord: An Influenza A virus is named according to the nomenclature, which includes the indication of the virus type (e.g., A for Influenza A), the place of collection, a sequence number, the year of collection, and the subtype of the virus (e.g., H3N2 or H1N2).
influenza-a-virus.Why does the Influenza A virus A/Califor: The Influenza A virus A/California/04/2009 has an unusual designation because it includes an additional descriptor, A(H1N1)pdm09, to distinguish it as the pandemic H1N1/09 virus lineage from older H1N1 viruses.
influenza-a-virus.How are some Influenza virus variants in: Some Influenza virus variants are informally identified and named according to their resembling isolate and presumed lineage, their typical host, their subtype, or their deadliness.
influenza-a-virus.What is an example of an Influenza virus: An example of an Influenza virus variant named after its resembling isolate is the Fujian flu virus-like.
influenza-a-virus.How are some Influenza virus variants na: Some Influenza virus variants are named according to their typical host, such as the human flu virus.
influenza-a-virus.What naming convention is used for Influ: Influenza virus variants are named based on their subtype, such as H3N2.
influenza-a-virus.Give an example of an Influenza virus va: An example of an Influenza virus variant named according to its deadliness is LP (Low pathogenic avian influenza).
influenza-a-virus.What is the significance of A/Darwin/9/2: A/Darwin/9/2021 (H3N2)-like virus is recommended by the WHO for flu shots in 2023-2024 in the northern hemisphere.
influenza-a-virus.What are some other names for the Annual: The Annual Flu is also called seasonal flu or human flu.
influenza-a-virus.How many deaths and hospitalizations doe: The Annual Flu results in around 36,000 deaths and over 200,000 hospitalizations each year.
influenza-a-virus.How much does the Annual Flu cost the US: The Annual Flu costs over $10 billion annually in the US.
influenza-a-virus.What is the estimated global death toll: The estimated global death toll of the Annual Flu each year is between 290,000 and 645,000 deaths.
influenza-a-virus.What components does the annually update: The annually updated trivalent influenza vaccine contains HA surface glycoprotein from components of H3N2, H1N1, and B influenza.
influenza-a-virus.How has the measured resistance to antiv: The measured resistance to antiviral drugs amantadine and rimantadine in H3N2 has increased from 1% to 12% to 91%.
influenza-a-virus.Where is contemporary H3N2 now endemic,: Contemporary H3N2 is now endemic in pigs in southern China and can reassort with avian H5N1 in this intermediate host.
influenza-a-virus.When was the FI6 antibody discovered?: The FI6 antibody was discovered in 2011.
influenza-a-virus.What is unique about FI6 compared to oth: FI6 is the only known antibody effective against all 16 subtypes of Influenza A virus (IAV).
influenza-a-virus.What is the genetic composition of Influ: Influenza A virus (IAV) is composed of single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) segmented genomes.
influenza-a-virus.When were the H17N10 and H18N11 subtypes: The H17N10 subtype was isolated from fruit bats in 2012, and the H18N11 subtype was discovered in a Peruvian bat in 2013.
influenza-a-virus.What is the size range of IAV virions?: IAV virions typically range in size from 80 to 120 nanometers in diameter.
influenza-a-virus.Describe the shape variation observed in: Influenza virions can exhibit pleomorphism, with some virions having an elliptical shape. Length can vary considerably, with some virions reaching tens of micrometers and producing filamentous forms.
influenza-a-virus.What is the function of hemagglutinin (H: HA mediates the binding of the virion to target cells and facilitates the entry of the viral genome into the target cell.
influenza-a-virus.What is the role of neuraminidase (NA) i: NA is involved in the release of the virus from abundant non-productive attachment sites in mucus, aiding in the spread of the virus within the host.
influenza-a-virus.How many subtypes of hemagglutinin (HA): There are 16 subtypes of HA and 9 subtypes of NA known in IAV, but only H1, H2, H3, and N1, N2 are commonly found in humans.
influenza-a-virus.What is contained within the central cor: The central core of IAV contains the viral genome and other viral proteins, which serve to package and protect the genome.
influenza-a-virus.How does the genetic composition of IAV: IAV has segmented pieces of negative-sense single-stranded RNA (-ssRNA), unlike complete RNA genomes found in some other viruses. Each segment typically codes for 1-2 proteins.
influenza-a-virus.What is the significance of the segmente: The segmented nature of the genome allows for the exchange of entire genes between different strains of IAV through a process known as reassortment.
influenza-a-virus.How long is the genome of IAV, and how m: The genome of IAV is 13,588 bases long and consists of eight RNA segments, each coding for 10-14 proteins depending on the strain.
influenza-a-virus.What proteins are encoded by Segment 1 o: Segment 1 encodes the RNA polymerase subunit PB2 (polymerase basic 2).
influenza-a-virus.What proteins are encoded by Segment 2 o: Segment 2 encodes the RNA polymerase subunit PB1 (polymerase basic 1) and the PB1-F2 protein, which induces cell death using different reading frames from the same RNA segment.
influenza-a-virus.What proteins are encoded by Segment 3 o: Segment 3 encodes the RNA polymerase subunit PA (polymerase acidic) and the PA-X protein, which plays a role in host transcription shutoff.
influenza-a-virus.What protein is encoded by Segment 4 of: Segment 4 encodes the Hemagglutinin (HA) protein, which is essential for determining the extent and severity of infection in a host. Approximately 500 HA molecules are needed per virion.
influenza-a-virus.What protein is encoded by Segment 6 of: Segment 6 encodes the Neuraminidase (NA) protein. Approximately 100 NA molecules are needed per virion.
influenza-a-virus.What proteins are encoded by Segment 7 o: Segment 7 encodes two matrix proteins, M1 and M2, using different reading frames from the same RNA segment. Around 3000 matrix protein molecules are needed per virion.
influenza-a-virus.What proteins are encoded by Segment 8 o: Segment 8 encodes two distinct nonstructural proteins, NS1 and NEP, by using different reading frames from the same RNA segment.
influenza-a-virus.What structural feature of Influenza A v: RNA segments of Influenza A virus have complementary base sequences at terminal ends, which allows for bonding via hydrogen bonds.
influenza-a-virus.Describe the process of transcription of: Transcription of the viral (-) sense genome (vRNA) in Influenza A virus proceeds after PB2 binds to host capped RNAs, allowing PA to cleave several nucleotides after the cap. The host-derived cap, accompanied by nucleotides, serves as the primer for transcription initiation. Transcription proceeds along vRNA until there is a stretch of U, which initiates stuttering. The nascent viral mRNA is then polyadenylated, producing a mature transcript for nuclear export and translation.
influenza-a-virus.Where does RNA synthesis take place in I: RNA synthesis takes place in the nucleus, while protein synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm of the host cell.
influenza-a-virus.Describe the process by which assembled: After viral proteins assemble, assembled virions leave the nucleus and migrate to the cell membrane. The host cell membrane contains patches of viral transmembrane proteins (HA, NA, M2) and an underlying layer of M1. M1 assists with budding through the membrane, facilitating the release of finished enveloped viruses into the extracellular fluid.
influenza-a-virus.What is multiplicity reactivation in the: Multiplicity reactivation is a phenomenon where inactivated Influenza A virus particles, damaged by UV radiation or ionizing radiation, can produce viable progeny when multiple damaged viruses infect the same host cell. This occurs if each of the eight viral genome segments is present in more than one undamaged copy, allowing for repair and reactivation of the damaged genomes.
influenza-a-virus.How does multiplicity reactivation occur: If any of the eight genome segments of Influenza A virus is damaged and prevents expression of an essential gene, the virus is not viable when it alone infects a cell. However, when two or more damaged viruses infect the same cell, viable progeny can be produced if each of the segments is present in more than one undamaged copy. This enables the damaged genomes to undergo repair and reactivate, leading to the production of functional viruses.
influenza-a-virus.What role does the host response play in: The host response, particularly the increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), can damage the viral genome. If the survival of the virus is vulnerable to oxidative damage, multiplicity reactivation becomes selectively advantageous as a genomic repair process, allowing the virus to overcome the effects of damage induced by radiation or other environmental factors.
influenza-a-virus.What is the significance of multiplicity: Multiplicity reactivation with segmented RNA genomes, such as that of Influenza A virus, may be analogous to an early form of sexual interaction in the RNA world. It provides a mechanism for genomic repair and ensures the survival and propagation of the virus in the face of environmental challenges, ultimately contributing to the virus's evolutionary resilience.
influenza-a-virus.What distinguishes the H1N1, H1N2, and H: The H1N1, H1N2, and H3N2 subtypes of human influenza virus are distinguished by the specific combinations of hemagglutinin (H) and neuraminidase (N) proteins they possess. These subtypes are named according to the types of H and N proteins they carry.
influenza-a-virus.What genetic factors differentiate human: Genetic factors that distinguish human flu viruses from avian influenza viruses include variations in the PB2 (RNA polymerase) and HA (hemagglutinin) proteins. Specifically, human flu viruses typically have a lysine (Lys) residue at position 627 of the PB2 protein, whereas avian flu viruses typically have a glutamic acid (Glu) residue at the same position. Additionally, avian flu HA proteins have a preference for binding to alpha 2-3 sialic acid receptors, while human flu HA proteins preferentially bind to alpha 2-6 sialic acid receptors.
influenza-a-virus.What are the symptoms associated with hu: Symptoms of human influenza include fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches, conjunctivitis (red eyes), breathing problems, and pneumonia. The severity of symptoms can vary depending on factors such as the individual's immune system status and previous exposure to similar strains of the virus.
influenza-a-virus.How does the receptor binding preference: Swine influenza viruses have the ability to bind to both alpha 2-3 and alpha 2-6 sialic acid receptors. This dual receptor binding property allows swine flu viruses to infect both avian and human hosts, contributing to their zoonotic potential and ability to cause outbreaks in both swine and human populations.
influenza-a-virus.What factors influence the severity of h: The severity of human influenza symptoms can be influenced by factors such as the individual's immune system status and previous exposure to similar strains of the virus. Partial immunity acquired from previous exposures can lead to milder symptoms, while individuals with compromised immune systems may experience more severe illness.
influenza-a-virus.What impact do follow-up studies suggest: Follow-up studies suggest that pretreatment with atorvastatin can suppress virus growth in culture, indicating a potential antiviral effect of statins.
influenza-a-virus.What is the mortality rate associated wi: HPH5N1 avian flu in humans is extremely fatal, with a mortality rate of approximately 50%.
influenza-a-virus.Describe a case of H5N1 avian flu infect: A boy infected with H5N1 avian flu exhibited diarrhea followed by a coma without developing typical respiratory or flu-like symptoms.
influenza-a-virus.What historical events are associated wi: The H1N1 subtype of influenza virus caused the Spanish flu pandemic in 1918 and the 2009 swine flu pandemic. Controversy arose regarding the publication of the H1N1 genome due to concerns about potential bioterrorism.
influenza-a-virus.Which subtype of influenza virus caused: The H2N2 subtype of influenza virus caused the Asian flu pandemic in 1957-1958 in China, and it spread worldwide the same year a flu vaccine was developed.
influenza-a-virus.What are some characteristics of the H3N: The H3N2 subtype of influenza virus caused the Hong Kong flu pandemic in 1968-1969. It is currently endemic in both human and pig populations and has evolved from H2N2 by antigenic shift. In late 2003, a severe form of H3N2 killed several children in the US. It became the dominant strain in January 2006 and exhibited a rapid increase in resistance to amantadine and rimantadine from 1994 to 2005. H3N2 is now endemic in pigs in southern China and circulates together with avian H5N1.
influenza-a-virus.What threat is associated with the H5N1: The H5N1 subtype of influenza virus is considered a global influenza pandemic threat, particularly through its spread in the mid-2000s.
influenza-a-virus.What information was reported by the Jap: The Japan Health Ministry reported that poultry farm workers in Ibaraki prefecture may have been exposed to H5N2 in 2005. Antibody titers of paired sera from 13 subjects showed an increase of more than fourfold.
influenza-a-virus.When was the first case of H5N8 reported: The first case of H5N8 was reported in Russia in February 2021.
influenza-a-virus.How many people were infected with H5N8: Seven people were infected with H5N8 in December 2020, and they have since recovered. There is no indication of human-to-human transmission.
influenza-a-virus.What is the significance of H7N2 in term: In 2003, one person in New York and in 2002, one person in Virginia had serologic evidence for H7N2 infection, and both fully recovered.
influenza-a-virus.What occurred in British Columbia regard: Presence of H7N3 was confirmed at several poultry farms in British Columbia in February 2004. Eighteen farms were quarantined, and two cases of avian influenza were confirmed in humans. Symptoms included conjunctivitis and mild influenza-like symptoms, but all affected individuals fully recovered.
influenza-a-virus.What is noteworthy about the zoonotic po: H7N7 has an unusual zoonotic potential. In 2003 in the Netherlands, 89 people were confirmed to have been infected after an outbreak in poultry on several farms, and one death was recorded.
influenza-a-virus.What was confirmed by the Centre for Hea: The CHP of Hong Kong confirmed four more cases of H7N9 on April 2, 2013, in the Jiangsu province, in addition to the three cases initially reported on March 31, 2013.
influenza-a-virus.According to Dr. Michael Greger, what is: Dr. Michael Greger stated that H7N9 has the greatest potential for an influenza pandemic among all the subtypes.
influenza-a-virus.What was confirmed regarding H9N2 avian: Low pathogenicity avian influenza A infection with H9N2 was confirmed in 1999 in China and Hong Kong in two children, and in 2003 in Hong Kong in one child, but all recovered.
influenza-a-virus.Where was H10N7 reported for the first t: H10N7 was reported for the first time in humans in Egypt in 2004. It caused illness in two infants, and one child's father was a poultry merchant.
influenza-a-virus.When and where was H10N3 reported for th: In May 2021 in Zhenjiang, China, H10N3 was reported for the first time in humans, although only one person was infected.
influenza-a-virus.What caused all IAV pandemics according: All IAV pandemics were caused by descendants of the 1918 virus, including drifted H1N1 and reassorted H2N2 and H3N2 viruses.
influenza-a-virus.How did H2N2 and H3N2 viruses acquire no: H2N2 and H3N2 viruses acquired novel surface proteins by incorporating avian influenza genes into their genomes, updating key genes.
influenza-a-virus.Describe the process of HA antigenic evo: In H3N2 viruses, most of the time, the HA gene showed no significant excess of mutations in antigenic regions as a variety of strains accumulated. However, one variant eventually gained higher fitness, becoming dominant during a brief interval of rapid evolution, which eliminated most other variants.
influenza-a-virus.What are the key processes in the short-: Stochastic processes are key processes in the short-term evolution of IAV. Evolution is dominated more by random importation of different viral strains from other geographic locations and less by natural selection. Adaptive evolution is infrequent and weak in a given season.
influenza-a-virus.How is the short-term evolution of IAV s: The short-term evolution of IAV is shaped by genetic diversity, rather than antigenic drift, through random migration and reassortment. Different strains are derived from newly imported genetic material, rather than isolates that had been circulating in previous seasons, indicating that gene flow is more important in the short term.
influenza-a-virus.What are natural asymptomatic carriers o: Fowl are natural asymptomatic carriers of avian influenza.
influenza-a-virus.Prior to the current H4N1 epizootic, whi: Prior to the current H4N1 epizootic, avian influenza strains had been transmitted from wildfowl to birds, pigs, horses, seals, whales, and humans, and between humans and pigs and humans and domestic fowl, but not to other pathways like domestic fowl to horses.
influenza-a-virus.What are some examples of animals that h: H5N1 avian influenza can be transmitted to tigers, leopards, and domestic cats that were fed uncooked domestic fowl with the virus.
influenza-a-virus.How do avian influenza viruses spread an: Avian influenza viruses spread in the air and in water and can survive longer in cold weather. They can also be transmitted by contaminated feed, water, equipment, and clothing. However, there isn't any evidence that the virus can survive in well-cooked meat.
influenza-a-virus.What are some symptoms caused by virulen: Virulent strains of avian influenza can cause a range of symptoms, but they can cause death within a few days in severe cases.
influenza-a-virus.Which avian influenza viruses does the W: The World Organization for Animal Health keeps track of avian influenza viruses such as H5N1, H7N2, H1N7, H7N3, H13N6, H5N9, H11N6, H3N8, H9N2, H5N2, H4N8, H10N7, H2N2, H8N4, H14N5, H6N5, and H12N5.
influenza-a-virus.What are the known subtypes of swine flu: The known subtypes of swine flu that are endemic in pigs are H1N1, H1N2, H3N1, and H3N2.
influenza-a-virus.What are the main types of horse flu?: The main types of horse flu are equine-1 (H7N7) and equine-2 (H3N8).
influenza-a-virus.Which subtype of IAV from horses has bee: H3N8 from horses has been known to infect dogs.
influenza-a-virus.Which subtype of IAV is associated with: The H3N8 subtype is associated with the dog flu outbreak at a Florida racetrack in January 2004.
influenza-a-virus.Which flu strains were discovered in Cen: H17N10 and H18N11 influenza A virus strains were discovered in Central and South American fruit bats.
influenza-a-virus.What is the initial characterization of: The initial characterization of the H18N11 flu strain suggests that the virus isn't well adapted to any other species than bats.
influenza-a-virus.What are neuraminidase inhibitors?: Neuraminidase inhibitors include zanamivir and oseltamivir.
influenza-a-virus.What are polymerase acidic endonuclease: Polymerase acidic endonuclease inhibitors include baloxavir marboxil.
influenza-a-virus.What are inhibitors of M2?: Inhibitors of M2 include amantadine and rimantadine.
influenza-a-virus.What happens with some strains of influe: Some strains have emerged to show drug resistance.
influenza-a-virus.When do antiviral drugs work optimally?: Antiviral drugs work optimally when taken a few days within onset of symptoms.
influenza-a-virus.What are the four licensed antiviral dru: The four licensed ones are zanamivir, oseltamivir phosphate, peramivir, and baloxavir marboxil.
influenza-a-virus.What is zanamivir and its common name?: Zanamivir is known as Relenza and is an N inhibitor against A and B.
influenza-a-virus.What is oseltamivir and its common name?: Oseltamivir is known as Tamiflu and is an N inhibitor against A and B.
influenza-a-virus.What is peramivir and its common name?: Peramivir is known as Rapivab and is an N inhibitor against A and B.
influenza-a-virus.What is baloxavir marboxil and its commo: Baloxavir marboxil is known as Xofluza and is a Cap-dependent endonuclease inhibitor against A and B.
influenza-a-virus.What is arbidol and where is it used?: Arbidol is used in Russia and China.
influenza-a-virus.What are interferons?: Interferons are cellular signaling factors produced in response to viral infection.
influenza-a-virus.Where did research on interferons begin?: Research on interferons started in the USSR at the height of the Hong Kong flu.
influenza-a-virus.What caused leukocytes to release interf: Leukocytes exposed to a high dose of Newcastle disease caused them to release interferons.
influenza-a-virus.How have interferons been investigated i: Interferons have been investigated as adjuvants to enhance influenza vaccine effectiveness.
influenza-a-virus.What was observed regarding the effectiv: Type I interferons were observed to enhance the effectiveness of the vaccine in mice.
influenza-a-virus.What did a clinical trial show about ora: A clinical trial showed that oral dosing with interferon-alpha reduced the immune response to the vaccine in elderly patients.
influenza-a-virus.What is Viferon and how is it administer: Viferon is a suppository containing non-pegylated interferon alpha-2b, ascorbic acid, and topopherol. It is effective against influenza and is administered as a suppository.
influenza-a-virus.What is Grippheron and how is it used?: Grippheron is another interferon alpha-2b medicine used for emergency protection against influenza. It is taken in nasal drops.
influenza-a-virus.For what purpose have manufacturers appe: Manufacturers have appealed to the WHO to consider Grippheron for use against H1N1 influenza.
influenza-a-virus.What mutation confers resistance to osel: The His274Tyr mutation in the NA protein confers resistance to oseltamivir in seasonal H1N1 swine flu.
influenza-a-virus.What is a contributing factor to the rap: The easy availability of amantadines as part of over-the-counter (OTC) cold remedies in China and Russia may contribute to the rapid production of resistant viruses under amantadine treatment.
influenza-a-virus.How do suboptimal doses of antiviral dru: Suboptimal doses of antiviral drugs, used as prophylactic measures, can contribute to the development of resistance even in the absence of drugs.
influenza-a-virus.Why did the CDC recommend oseltamivir as: H2N2 is becoming more resistant to amantadine and rimantadine, leading the CDC to recommend oseltamivir as a prophylactic drug against it.
influenza-a-virus.What are analgesics commonly used for in: Analgesics are commonly used for fever, aches, pains, sinus pressure, and sore throat in treating influenza symptoms.
influenza-a-virus.What are decongestants typically used fo: Decongestants are typically used for nasal congestion and sinus pressure in treating influenza symptoms.
influenza-a-virus.What are antihistamines used for in trea: Antihistamines are used for sinus pressure, runny nose, watery eyes, and cough in treating influenza symptoms.
influenza-a-virus.What is the purpose of cough suppressant: Cough suppressants are used to alleviate cough symptoms in influenza treatment.
influenza-a-virus.What are local anesthetics used for in t: Local anesthetics are used for sore throat in treating influenza symptoms.
influenza-a-virus.Why should children and teenagers avoid: Children and teenagers should avoid taking aspirin during influenza because it can lead to Reye syndrome, a serious condition affecting the brain.
influenza-a-virus.What medications may prove useful in tre: Statin drugs, fibrates, and chloroquine may prove useful in treating an H5N1 outbreak.
influenza-a-virus.What is the mechanism of action of N-ace: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) shifts cell-mediated immunity from anergy to normoergy, blocks cytopathic effects of influenza-infected macrophages, reduces DNA fragmentation in cells, and reduces RANTES production in airway cells.
influenza-a-virus.How does elderberry affect influenza sym: Elderberry reduces influenza symptoms by raising cytokine levels, but it may be imprudent in cases where death is caused by a cytokine storm leading to primary viral pneumonia.
influenza-a-virus.What is 'Kan Jang' and how is it used fo: 'Kan Jang' is a mixture of Siberian ginseng and Androgrpahic paniculata used for treatment.
influenza-a-virus.How does green tea help reduce the risk: Green tea contains catechins and theanine, which reduce the risk of getting influenza by inhibiting viral replication.
influenza-a-virus.What is an alternative to vaccination fo: An alternative to vaccination is transfused antibodies for preventing influenza.
influenza-a-virus.What has been done with CD8+ cytotoxic T: Clonal populations of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells have been grown to carry T cell receptors specific to influenza for treatment.

hbv.What is Hepatitis B caused by?: Hepatitis B is caused by the Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) and affects the liver.
hbv.What type of infection does Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B causes both acute and chronic infections.
hbv.What are some common symptoms of Hepatit: Common symptoms of Hepatitis B infection include nausea, vomiting, yellow skin (jaundice), fatigue, dark urine, and abdominal pain.
hbv.How long does acute Hepatitis B infectio: Acute Hepatitis B infection typically lasts for a few weeks, but some individuals may feel sick for less than 6 months.
hbv.What percentage of individuals infected: Approximately 90% of individuals infected with HBV after birth develop chronic Hepatitis B (cHBV).
Less than 10% of individuals infected with HBV after the age of 5 develop chronic Hepatitis B (cHBV).
hbv.What are some long-term complications of: Long-term complications of chronic Hepatitis B infection may include cirrhosis and liver cancer, which eventually develop in approximately 25% of those with chronic infection.
