hbv.How is Hepatitis B transmitted?: Hepatitis B is transmitted through exposure to infectious blood or bodily fluids.
hbv.What are the most common methods of tran: In areas where Hepatitis B is common, infection around birth or from blood are the most frequent methods of transmission.
hbv.What are some other risk factors for Hep: Other risk factors for Hepatitis B transmission include blood transfusion, working in healthcare, dialysis, living with an infected person, travel in high-prevalence countries, and living in an institution.
hbv.Why has the transmission of Hepatitis B: Transmission of Hepatitis B through tattooing and acupuncture has decreased due to improved sterilization practices.
hbv.What are some common misconceptions abou: HBV can't be spread by holding hands, sharing utensils, kissing, hugging, coughing, sneezing, or breastfeeding.
hbv.How long after exposure is Hepatitis B t: Hepatitis B is typically diagnosed 30-60 days after exposure, and diagnosis is usually confirmed by blood testing for parts of the virus and antibodies against it.
hbv.What are some other types of Hepatitis v: Other Hepatitis viruses include Hepatitis A, C, D, and E.
hbv.How is care typically managed during the: During the initial infection of HBV, care is typically based on managing symptoms.
hbv.What are some treatment options for chro: In chronic Hepatitis B (cHBV), antiviral medications like tenofovir and interferon can be used, although they are expensive. Liver transplantation is recommended for cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.
hbv.How effective is the HBV vaccine?: The HBV vaccine is preventable and is 98-100% effective. It is administered in several doses, usually 3-4 doses. WHO recommends vaccination within 24 hours after birth.
hbv.What measures does WHO recommend for pre: WHO recommends testing donated blood for HBV before transfusion, antiviral prophylaxis to prevent mother-to-child transmission, and following safe sex practices (e.g., using condoms).
hbv.What is WHO's goal regarding viral hepat: WHO set a goal of eliminating viral hepatitis by 2030, but achieving this goal requires the development of therapeutic treatments to cure chronic Hepatitis B, prevention of transmission, and widespread vaccination.
hbv.What percentage of the global population: 3.8% of the global population has chronic Hepatitis B (cHBV).
hbv.What are the leading causes of death ass: Cirrhosis and liver cancer are the leading causes of death associated with chronic Hepatitis B (cHBV).
hbv.Where is HBV most prevalent and where ar: HBV is most prevalent in Africa and the Western Pacific, while infection rates are low in Europe and the Americas.
hbv.What was HBV originally known as?: HBV was originally known as serum hepatitis.
hbv.What are the typical signs and symptoms: Acute Hepatitis B infection is associated with general ill health, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, body aches, mild fever, dark urine, and eventually jaundice. It typically lasts for a few weeks and improves gradually.
hbv.What is the severe form of acute Hepatit: A severe form of acute Hepatitis B infection is fulminant hepatic failure, which may lead to death as a result.
hbv.Is Hepatitis B infection always symptoma: No, Hepatitis B infection may be asymptomatic and may go unrecognized.
hbv.What are the long-term consequences of c: Chronic Hepatitis B infection may be asymptomatic or associated with chronic inflammation of the liver (chronic hepatitis), which can progress to cirrhosis over several years. This type of infection increases the incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma.
hbv.What are chronic carriers of Hepatitis B: Chronic carriers of Hepatitis B are encouraged to avoid alcohol, as it increases the risk of cirrhosis and liver cancer.
hbv.What other health conditions are linked: Hepatitis B is linked to the development of membranous glomerulonephritis.
hbv.What percentage of Hepatitis B-infected: Between 1-10% of Hepatitis B-infected individuals experience symptoms outside of the liver. Examples include serum-sickness-like syndrome, acute necrotizing vasculitis (polyarteritis nodosa), membranous glomerulonephritis, and papular acrodermatitis of childhood (Gianotti-Crosti syndrome). Serum-sickness-like syndrome occurs in the setting of acute Hepatitis B and precedes the onset of jaundice.
hbv.What are the common clinical features of: Common clinical features of serum-sickness-like syndrome associated with Hepatitis B infection include fever, skin rash, and polyarteritis.
hbv.How long do symptoms of serum-sickness-l: Symptoms of serum-sickness-like syndrome associated with acute Hepatitis B infection often subside shortly after the onset of jaundice but can persist throughout the duration of acute Hepatitis B infection.
hbv.What percentage of people with polyarter: Approximately 30-50% of people with polyarteritis nodosa are carriers of Hepatitis B virus.
hbv.What is HBV-associated nephropathy, and: HBV-associated nephropathy is a condition described in adults but is more common in children, with membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) being the most common form.
hbv.What are some immune-mediated hematologi: Other immune-mediated hematological disorders associated with Hepatitis B virus infection include essential mixed cryoglobulinemia and aplastic anemia. However, the association isn't well-defined, and these disorders probably shouldn't be etiologically linked to Hepatitis B virus.
hbv.What are the main routes of transmission: Transmission is by infectious blood or bodily fluids with blood. It can be transmitted through several routes, including vertical transmission during childbirth, early-life horizontal transmission through bites, lesions, sanitary habits, or contact with secretions/saliva containing HBV, and adult horizontal transmission through sexual contact, blood transfusion, transfusion with other human blood products, and re-use of contaminated needles and syringes.
hbv.How infectious is Hepatitis B virus comp: Hepatitis B virus is 50-100 times more infectious than HIV.
hbv.What is the risk of vertical transmissio: In vertical transmission, HBV is transmitted MTCT during childbirth and a mother who is positive for HBsAg has a 20% risk of passing infection to her offspring at birth, increasing to 90% if the mother is also positive for HBeAg.
hbv.What is the classification of Hepatitis: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a partially double-stranded DNA virus belonging to group VII. It is a species of the Orthohepadnavirus genus in the Hepadnaviridae family.
hbv.What is HBV's classification in terms of: HBV is the only member of the viral order Blubervirales.
hbv.Where have viruses similar to HBV been f: Viruses similar to HBV have been found in all apes, Old World monkeys, and New World woolly monkeys.
hbv.How is HBV divided into major serotypes?: HBV is divided into four major serotypes: adr, adw, ayr, and ayw. These serotypes are based on antigenic epitopes on the envelope protein surface.
hbv.What determines the serotypes of HBV?: The serotypes of HBV are determined based on a common determinant (a) and two mutually exclusive determinant pairs (d/y and w/r) on the envelope protein surface.
hbv.How is HBV divided into genotypes and su: HBV is divided into ten genotypes (A-J) and 40 subgenotypes based on nucleotide sequence. These genotypes have distinct geographical distributions and trace the virus's evolution and transmission.
hbv.What is the significance of HBV genotype: Differences in HBV genotypes affect the severity, course, likelihood of complications, and response to treatment. For example, genotype D has 10 subgenotypes.
hbv.Where have unclassified HBV-like species: Unclassified HBV-like species have been isolated from bats.
hbv.What is the structure of the Hepatitis B: The HBV particle, also known as a Dane particle or virion, has an outer lipid envelope with an icosahedral nucleocapsid core composed of protein. The nucleocapsid encloses viral DNA and a DNA polymerase with reverse transcriptase (RT) activity.
hbv.What is the composition of the outer env: The outer envelope of the HBV particle contains embedded proteins involved in viral binding and entry.
hbv.What is the size of the HBV virion?: HBV is one of the smallest enveloped animal viruses, with a virion diameter of 42 nm. However, pleomorphic forms also exist, such as filamentous and spherical forms without a core.
hbv.What is HBsAg and its role in the HBV li: HBsAg, or surface antigen, is the lipid and protein on the virion surface of HBV. It is produced in excess during the HBV life cycle.
hbv.What are the components of the hepatitis: HBsAg consists of small (S), medium (M), and large (L) proteins.
hbv.What is the function of hepatitis B core: HBcAg functions in replication and contributes to capsid formation, which is essential for infection. It also contributes to clearance in vivo.
hbv.What is the role of hepatitis B virus DN: Hepatitis B virus DNA polymerase is incorporated into the nucleocapsid with the pre-genomic RNA (pgRNA). Inside the capsid, pgRNA undergoes reverse transcription (RT) to create the (-) DNA strand.
hbv.What is the function of hepatitis B enve: HBeAg is found between the nucleocapsid core and the lipid envelope of HBV. It is considered nonparticulate, secreted, and accumulates in serum. It is made in the same reading frame as HBcAg.
hbv.What is HBx, and what role does it play: HBx is a small, nonstructural protein that plays a role in liver disease and HBV replication in HepG2 cells. It is multifunctional and activates signaling pathways for infection.
hbv.What is the relationship between hepatit: HDV requires HBV envelope particles to become virulent.
hbv.What evidence suggests a long coevolutio: The identification of endogenous hepadnaviridae elements in avian species, which show over 70 million years of existence, suggests a long coevolution of hepadnaviruses with vertebrates.
hbv.What does the phylogenetic position of o: The phylogenetic position of orthohepadnaviruses as a sister clade to avihepadnaviruses suggests the presence of HBV in the amniote ancestor and coevolution with both birds and mammals after their divergence, over 300 million years ago.
hbv.What might be the origin of primate hepa: Recent research suggests that New World bat hepadnavirus might be the origin of primate hepadnaviruses.
hbv.What is the significance of the presence: The presence of a vestigial X RF in the genome of duck hepadnavirus suggests that X protein may have evolved from a DNA glycosylase.
hbv.How has the reconstruction of HBV genome: The reconstruction of HBV genomes from ancient humans has allowed for detailed investigation of HBV evolution. It revealed the presence of HBV in humans over 10,000 years ago and provided insights into human migration patterns and Neolithic transitions.
hbv.What can be inferred from studies on anc: Studies on ancient HBV strains suggest that some ancient strains still infect humans, while others are extinct. HBV strains in African and Southeast Asian apes appear related to modern human HBV.
hbv.What is known about the origin and sprea: The ancestor of subgenotype B5, which is isolated from the circumpolar Arctic human population, may have originated in Asia 2000 years ago. Coalescence occurred around 1000 AD, and the subgenotype spread to Greenland and then westward.
hbv.What is the structure of the HBV genome?: The HBV genome is made of circular DNA, but the DNA isn’t fully double-stranded. One end of the strand is linked to viral DNA Pol.
hbv.What are the typical sizes of the HBV ge: The HBV genome ranges from 3020 to 3220 nucleotides in full length and from 1700 to 2800 nucleotides in short length.
hbv.How is the HBV genome encoded?: The (-) strand of the HBV genome is complementary to viral mRNA, and viral DNA is found in the nucleus soon after infection. Partial dsDNA is rendered fully dsDNA by completing the (+) strand via cellular DNA Pol. The viral DNA Pol is used later in this process. The process also involves the removal of the viral polymerase protein, P, from the (-) strand and short sequences of RNA from the (+) strand. Noncoding bases are removed from the ends of the (-) strand, and the ends are rejoined. Viral genes are transcribed by cellular RNA Pol II in the nucleus from a covalently circular DNA (cccDNA) template.
hbv.What are Enhancer I (EnhI) and Enhancer: Enhancer I (EnhI) and enhancer II (EnhII) are regulatory elements identified in the HBV genome. They exhibit greater activity in cells of hepatic origin and together drive and regulate the expression of complete viral transcripts.
hbv.What are the encoding genes of HBV?: The encoding genes of HBV are C, P, S, and X.
hbv.Which protein is coded by gene C?: The core protein (HBcAg) is coded by gene C, and the start codon is preceded by an upstream AUG where the pre-core protein is made.
hbv.How is HBeAg produced?: HBeAg is produced by proteolytic processing of the pre-core protein.
hbv.Are there any rare strains of HBV where: Yes, in some rare strains called hepatitis B virus precore mutants, no HBeAg is present.
hbv.Which protein is encoded by gene P?: DNA Pol is encoded by gene P.
hbv.What is the function of the protein enco: The protein encoded by gene S is HBsAg, which is one long open reading frame (ORF) that has three in-frame “start” ATG codons that divide the gene into pre-S1, pre-S2, and S sections.
hbv.What is the significance of the myristyl: The myristyl group plays an important role in infection by facilitating virus attachment.
hbv.What is the function of the protein enco: The function of the protein encoded by gene X is not fully understood, but some evidence suggests that it might function as a transcriptional transactivator, promoting cell growth and inactivating growth-regulating molecules.
hbv.What is the 40-kDa X-core fusion protein: The 40-kDa X-core fusion protein is encoded by a long 3.9kb transcript without a fully understood function. Its synthesis begins at the X promoter region, and the transcript is polyadenylated after the 2nd round of transcription.
hbv.What non-coding RNA elements have been i: Several non-coding RNA elements have been identified, including HBV PREalpha, HBV PREbeta, and HBV RNA encapsidation signal epsilon.
hbv.What are genotypes in the context of HBV: Genotypes in the context of HBV refer to variations of the virus that differ by more than 8% of the sequence and have distinct geographical distributions.
hbv.How much do subgenotypes differ from eac: Subgenotypes of HBV differ by 4-8% of the genome.
hbv.How many known genotypes of HBV are ther: There are eight known genotypes labeled A-H, with an additional genotype labeled I, although it has not been fully accepted yet.
hbv.How many subtypes of HBV are there?: There are at least 24 subtypes of HBV.
hbv.How do different genotypes of HBV respon: Different genotypes of HBV respond to treatment in different ways.
hbv.What is the most divergent type of HBV?: Type F is the most divergent type of HBV.
hbv.Where is Type A prevalent?: Type A is prevalent in Europe, Africa, and Southeast Asia.
hbv.Which types of HBV are predominant in As: Types B and C are predominant in Asia.
hbv.Where is Type D common?: Type D is common in the Mediterranean area, Middle East, and India.
hbv.Where is Type E found?: Type E is found in sub-Saharan Africa.
hbv.Where are Type F and H restricted to?: Type F and H are restricted to Central and South America.
hbv.Where has Type G been found?: Type G has been found in France and Germany.
hbv.Which genotypes are predominant in Brazi: Genotypes A, D, and F are predominant in Brazil.
hbv.Do all genotypes of HBV occur in the US?: Yes, all genotypes occur in the US with different ethnic frequencies.
hbv.Which genotypes of HBV appear to have or: Genotypes E and F appear to have originated in aboriginal populations of Africa and the New World.
hbv.How many subtypes does Type A have and w: Type A has two subtypes: Aa/A1 in Africa/Asia and the Philippines, and Ae/A2 in Europe/US.
hbv.What are the geographical distinctions f: Type B has two geographical distinctions: Bj/B1 for Japan, and Ba/B2 for Asia.
hbv.How many subtypes does Type C have and w: Type C has geographic subtypes: Cs/C1 for Southeast Asia, and Ce/C2 for East Asia. Additionally, subtypes C3-C5 have been described, along with another subtype in Papua, Indonesia.
hbv.How many subtypes does Type F have and w: Type F has four subtypes, F1-F4, which further divide into 1a and 1b.
hbv.Where are the subtypes F1, F2, and F3 fo: Subtypes F1, F2, and F3 are found in East and West Amerindians in Venezuela, while South Amerindians only have subtype F3.
hbv.Which subtypes of Type I have limited ge: Subtypes Ia, III, and IV have limited geographic distribution, located in Central America, North of South America, and South of South America respectively.
hbv.Where are the Clades Ib and II found?: Clades Ib and II are found in all Americas except North South America and North America respectively.
hbv.What are the serotypes of HBV based on?: Serotypes of HBV are divided into adr, adw, ayr, and ayw based on antigenic epitopes on envelope proteins.
hbv.What is the initial step of HBV infectio: The initial step of HBV infection is attachment, during which the virus binds to receptors on the cell surface.
hbv.What receptors does HBV initially bind t: HBV initially binds to heparin sulfate proteoglycan and later binds tightly to the surface receptor sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide (NTCP) encoded by SLC10A1.
hbv.Where is NTCP mostly found in liver cell: NTCP is mostly found in the sinusoidal membrane of liver cells.
hbv.What happens after HBV enters the cell v: After endocytosis, fusion of membranes occurs, and the nucleocapsid is released into the cytoplasm.
hbv.How is the genomic DNA of HBV transferre: The capsid containing the genomic DNA of HBV is transported on microtubules to the nuclear pore via chaperones, where uncoating occurs.
hbv.What is the role of host DNA Pol in the: Host DNA Pol is responsible for transforming the partially double-stranded DNA of HBV into fully double-stranded DNA in the nucleus, which then forms covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA) serving as a template for viral transcription.
hbv.What are the two types of endocytosis in: HBV enters cells via clathrin-mediated endocytosis or caveolin-1 endocytosis.
hbv.What is the function of the largest mRNA: The largest mRNA is used to make copies of the genome, the capsid core protein, and the viral RNA-dependent-DNA-polymerase.
hbv.What happens during the assembly phase o: During the assembly phase, the four transcripts undergo more processing and form progeny virions.
hbv.How does HBV release from the cell occur: HBV release from the cell occurs when the long mRNA goes into the cytoplasm, where the virion P protein synthesizes DNA via reverse transcriptase (RT) activity.
hbv.What is the functional receptor for HBV?: The functional receptor for HBV is NTCP (sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide).
hbv.How does HBV bind to host cells?: HBV binds to host cells via the preS domain of the viral surface antigen and is internalized by endocytosis.
hbv.Where are HBV-preS-specific receptors pr: HBV-preS-specific receptors are primarily expressed on hepatocytes.
hbv.What role does the adaptive immune respo: The adaptive immune response, especially cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), contributes to most of the liver injury from HBV infection. CTLs eliminate HBV infection by killing infected cells and producing antiviral cytokines.
hbv.How is liver damage initiated and mediat: Liver damage is initiated and mediated by cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) during HBV infection, although antigen-nonspecific inflammatory cells can worsen CTL-induced immunopathology, and activated platelets may facilitate accommodation of CTLs in the liver.
hbv.What are some common assays used to dete: Assays used to detect HBV involve serum or blood tests that detect either viral antigens or antibodies.
hbv.Which viral antigen is most frequently u: HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) is most frequently used to screen for HBV infection.
hbv.What is the significance of IgM antibodi: During the window in which the host is infected but has cleared the virus, IgM antibodies specific to hepatitis B core antigen (anti-HBc IgM) may be the only serological evidence of disease.
hbv.What are some components typically inclu: Most HBV panels contain HBsAg and total anti-HBc (both IgM and IgG).
hbv.What does the appearance of HBeAg in ser: The appearance of HBeAg in serum during HBV infection is traditionally associated with high rates of replication and infectivity.
hbv.What is the significance of the appearan: The appearance of antibodies to e antigen (anti-HBe) during HBV infection is associated with a massive decline in viral replication.
hbv.What is the significance of the 'window: The 'window period' in HBV diagnosis refers to the time between the removal of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies. During this period, individuals may be negative for HBsAg but positive for anti-HBs, indicating either clearance of infection or previous vaccination.
hbv.How are chronic HBV carriers identified?: Individuals who remain HBsAg positive for more than 6 months are considered chronic HBV carriers.
hbv.What is the significance of elevated ser: Elevated serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels in chronic HBV carriers reflect liver inflammation, especially if in the immune clearance phase.
hbv.What complications or risks are associat: Chronic HBV carriers who have seroconverted to HBeAg-negative status, especially those who acquired the infection as adults, may have very little viral multiplication and may be at risk of long-term complications or transmitting the infection.
hbv.What is the significance of PCR tests in: PCR tests can detect and measure HBV DNA (viral load) in clinical specimens, which is important for assessing a person's infection status and monitoring treatment.
hbv.What is meant by 'immune escape' in the: In the context of HBV infection, 'immune escape' refers to a phenomenon where individuals with HBeAg-negative hepatitis B exhibit reduced immune response, potentially allowing the virus to evade immune surveillance and persist in the host.
hbv.How is the protective response to the HB: The protective response to the HBV vaccine is defined as an anti-HBs antibody concentration of greater than 10 mIU/mL in the serum.
hbv.What is the effectiveness of the HBV vac: The HBV vaccine is highly effective in children, with a threshold protection level of 95%.
hbv.How does the effectiveness of the HBV va: The effectiveness of the HBV vaccine decreases with age, dropping to around 90% at 40 years and 75% at 60 years.
hbv.Is protection provided by the HBV vaccin: Yes, protection provided by the HBV vaccine is long-lasting, even after antibody levels fall below 10 mIU/mL.
hbv.What strategies are recommended for prev: For newborns of HBsAg+ mothers, HBV vaccine alone, HBV Ig alone, or the combination of both are recommended to prevent HBV occurrence. The combination of vaccine and HBV Ig is considered superior to vaccine alone.
hbv.How can tenofovir be used to reduce moth: Tenofovir given in the 2nd-3rd trimester can reduce MTCT by 77% when combined with HBV Ig and HBV vaccine, especially for pregnant women with high HBV DNA levels.
hbv.Who is recommended to receive HBV vaccin: All people at risk of exposure to body fluids like blood, as well as high-risk groups such as healthcare workers, people with chronic kidney failure, and homosexual men, are recommended to receive HBV vaccination.
hbv.What is recommended for verifying effect: Testing to verify effective immunization is recommended, and further doses are given to those who are not sufficiently immunized.
hbv.What is the comparative effectiveness of: Both plasma-derived (PDV) and recombinant vaccines (RV) for HBV have similar effectiveness in preventing infection in both healthcare workers and those with chronic kidney failure.
hbv.Which route of administration is more ef: The intramuscular route of administration is more effective for recombinant HBV vaccine in health workers compared to the intradermal route.
hbv.Is sperm washing necessary for males wit: Sperm washing isn't necessary for males with HBV to prevent transmission unless the female partner has been effectively vaccinated.
hbv.Is the risk of mother-to-child transmiss: No, the risk of MTCT with IVF isn't different from the risk in spontaneous conception for females with HBV.
hbv.Which groups are recommended for screeni: Groups recommended for screening for HBV include non-vaccinated individuals, people from areas of the world where HBV prevalence is greater than 2%, those with HIV, intravenous drug users, homosexual men, and those living with a person with HBV.
hbv.Is screening during pregnancy recommende: Yes, screening during pregnancy is recommended in the US.
hbv.Do individuals with acute HBV usually re: No, most adults with acute HBV clear the infection spontaneously and don't require treatment.
hbv.When might early antiviral treatment be: Early antiviral treatment may be necessary in cases of fulminant hepatitis or in people who are immunocompromised.
hbv.Why is treatment of chronic HBV infectio: Treatment of chronic HBV infection may be necessary to reduce the risk of cirrhosis and liver cancer.
hbv.Who are candidates for therapy for chron: Chronically infected individuals with persistently elevated ALT levels (liver damage indicators) and HBV DNA levels are candidates for therapy.
hbv.How long does treatment for HBV typicall: Treatment typically lasts 6 months to 1 year depending on genotype and medication. Treatment duration with oral medication alone is usually longer, often more than 1 year.
hbv.What is the goal of available HBV medica: None of the available medications clear the infection but can stop replication, which minimizes liver damage.
hbv.What are some examples of antiviral medi: Lamivudine, adefovir, tenofovir disoproxil, tenofovir alafenamide, telbivudine, and entecavir are the approved antiviral medications for HBV treatment.
hbv.Which medications does the WHO recommend: The WHO recommends tenofovir or entecavir as first-line agents for HBV treatment.
hbv.What are some examples of immune system: Interferon alpha-2a and PEGylated interferon alpha-2a are immune system modulators used to treat HBV.
hbv.How does treatment affect HBV replicatio: Treatment reduces replication in the liver and lowers the viral load.
hbv.How does response to treatment differ be: Response to treatment differs between HBV genotypes.
hbv.What progress has been made in therapeut: While HBV is unlikely to be eliminated by 2030, progress is being made in therapeutic treatments.
hbv.What is the likelihood of children clear: Children are less likely than adults to clear the infection, with less than 30% of younger children and only 5% of newborns who acquire the infection through mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) clearing the infection.
hbv.What is the lifetime risk of death from: There is a 40% lifetime risk of death from cirrhosis or HCC associated with chronic HBV infection.
hbv.At what age do approximately 70% of indi: Approximately 70% of individuals clear HBV infection between the ages of 1 and 6 years old.
hbv.What is the significance of HDV infectio: HDV infection can only occur with concomitant HBV infection since HDV uses HBV surface antigen to form a capsid.
hbv.How does coinfection with HDV affect the: Coinfection with HDV increases the risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) associated with HBV infection.
hbv.What other condition is more common in i: Polyarteritis nodosa is more common in people with HBV.
hbv.What is the test of choice for diagnosin: Transient elastography (FibroScan) is the test of choice for diagnosing cirrhosis.
hbv.What alternative test may be used for di: Aspartate aminotransferase to platelet ratio index may be used for diagnosing cirrhosis when cost is an issue.
hbv.What is reactivation of HBV and when is: Reactivation of HBV occurs when HBV DNA remains in the body after infection and recurs in some individuals, particularly following alcohol or drug use or in immunocompromised people.
hbv.What factors increase the risk of reacti: Factors that increase the risk of HBV reactivation include baseline ALT levels of 200 UL/L or higher in males, chemotherapy, and the use of immunosuppressive drugs.
hbv.Who is at the greatest risk of HBV react: Individuals with detectable HBsAg in the blood are at the greatest risk of HBV reactivation.
hbv.Are individuals with antibodies to the s: Presence of antibodies to the surface antigen is considered a marker of immunity but does not preclude reactivation.

t4.What type of bacteria does T4 Phage infe: T4 Phage infects E. coli bacteria.
t4.What is the genetic composition of T4 Ph: T4 Phage is a dsDNA virus belonging to the subfamily Tevenvirinae within the family Myoviridae.
t4.Which type of life cycle can T4 Phage un: T4 Phage can only undergo the lytic cycle and not the lysogenic cycle.
t4.What was T4 Phage formerly named, and wh: T4 Phage was formerly named T-even bacteriophage, which also encompassed Enterobacteria phage T2, T4, and T6.
t4.What are T-even phages considered in res: T-even phages are considered model organisms.
t4.What are the requirements for model orga: Model organisms are required to be simple with as few as 5 genes, yet T-even phages are among the largest and highest complexity viruses, with a genome made up of around 300 genes.
t4.What is an unusual base found in T-even: T-even phages have the unusual base hydroxymethylcytosine in place of cytosine.
t4.What is the length of the T4 phage genom: The T4 phage genome is 160 kilobase pairs long and encodes 269 proteins.
t4.Describe the structure of the T4 phage g: During replication, the T4 phage genome forms long multi-genome length concatemers via rolling circle replication. These concatemers are then cut at unspecific positions of the same length when packaged, resulting in several genomes that are circular permutations of the original.
t4.What unique feature does the T4 phage ge: The T4 phage genome bears eukaryote-like intron sequences.
t4.What sequence dominates in T4 early gene: The SD sequence GAGG dominates in T4 early genes.
t4.What is the role of the sequence GGAG in: The sequence GGAG is a target for T4 endonuclease RegB, which initiates early mRNA degradation.
t4.What is the role of the tail in the T4 p: The tail is hollow to allow the passage of nucleic acid into the cell after attachment.
t4.What is the significance of tail fibers: Tail fibers are crucial for recognizing host cell surface receptors to determine if a bacterium is within the host range.
t4.What is the composition of the baseplate: The baseplate consists of 127 PP chains of 13 different proteins, including gene products 5, 5.4, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 25, 27, 48, and 53.
t4.What proteins are involved in the format: The tail tube is formed by gp54 and the main tube protein gp19.
t4.What is the role of the tape measure pro: The tape measure protein gp29 is found in the baseplate-tail tube complexes.
t4.What is the significance of maintaining: Maintaining a balance of proteins is important for normal morphogenesis.
t4.What are the categories of proteins enco: The proteins include major structural components, minor structural components, and nonstructural proteins that catalyze steps in morphogenesis.
t4.How is T4 morphogenesis divided in terms: T4 morphogenesis is divided into three pathways: head, tail, and long tail fibers.
t4.How is the infection process of T4 phage: Initiated infection by binding OmpC porin and LPS on surface of E. coli through its LTFs.
t4.What happens after the recognition signa: After the recognition signal is sent through the LTFs to the baseplate, the short tail fibers (STFs) are unraveled and bind irreversibly to the E. coli surface.
t4.What occurs when the baseplate changes c: When the baseplate changes conformation and the tail sheath contracts, GP5 at the end of the tail tube punctures the outer membrane of E. coli.
t4.What is the role of GP5 in the T4 phage: GP5, located at the end of the tail tube, punctures the outer membrane of E. coli after the baseplate changes conformation and the tail sheath contracts. The lysozyme domain of GP5 is then activated and degrades the periplasmic peptidoglycan (PG), allowing the DNA from the head to travel through the tail tube and enter the cell.
t4.Who provided evidence that phage DNA ent: Hershey and Chase provided evidence that phage DNA enters the bacterial cell upon infection and is the genetic material of the phage. Their work suggested that DNA is the genetic material of different organisms.
t4.What is the approximate duration of the: The lytic cycle of T4 phage takes approximately 30 minutes at 37°C.
t4.How do virulent phages like T4 multiply: Virulent phages multiply in their host immediately after entry. Once the number of progeny phages reaches a threshold, they cause the host to lyse, resulting in host lysis.
t4.What are the essential steps that T4 pha: T4 phage must go through adsorption and penetration (immediately), arrest of host gene expression (immediately), enzyme synthesis (after 5 minutes), DNA replication (after 10 minutes), and formation of new virions (after 12 minutes) during the lytic cycle.
t4.What is the burst size of T4 phage, appr: T4 phage has a burst size of approximately 100-150 virions per infected host.
t4.What techniques did Benzer develop to st: Benzer developed a system to study the fine structure of genes using T4 mutants defective in rIIA and rIIB. The techniques employed were complementation tests and crosses to detect recombination between deletion mutations.
t4.What are the various receptors on the su: T-even phages can bind to receptors on the surface of the host, which vary depending on the host. These receptors include teichoic acid, cell wall proteins, LPS, flagella, and pili.
t4.Describe the two processes involved in a: Adsorption of T-even phages to the host occurs in two processes: reversible and irreversible. Reversible adsorption involves the binding of tail fibers to the appropriate receptor, while irreversible adsorption is mediated by one or more components of the base plate.
t4.What is the role of the phage tail struc: The phage tail structure is involved in the adsorption process when tail fibers bind to the appropriate receptor on the host cell.
t4.When does penetration of genetic materia: Penetration of genetic material into the host cell occurs after the irreversible adsorption phase. The mechanisms for penetration can vary depending on the phage and may involve electrochemical membrane potential, ATP molecules, enzymatic splitting of peptidoglycan (PG), or a combination of these mechanisms.
t4.How does the penetration mechanism diffe: Studies on T2 (T4-like) phages have shown that the phage's tail does not penetrate inside the cell wall. Instead, penetration involves the electrochemical membrane potential on the inner membrane.
t4.How is the T4 genome synthesized within: The T4 genome is synthesized within the host cell via rolling circle replication.
t4.How is the rate of T4 DNA elongation mea: The rate of T4 DNA elongation is measured as the rate of T4 DNA elongation in a virus-infected E. coli cell. During the exponential phase at 37°C, the rate was observed to be 749 nucleotides per second (nt/s).
t4.What is the mutation rate per base pair: The mutation rate per base pair per replication for T4 DNA replication is 1.7 * 10^-8, indicating a very accurate copying mechanism.
t4.Describe the process of T4 head assembly: The T4 head is assembled empty around a scaffolding protein and is later degraded. DNA enters the prohead through a tiny pore, which is achieved by a hexamer of gp17 interacting with DNA first, serving as a motor and nuclease.
t4.What is the rate at which the T4 packagi: The T4 packaging motor can load DNA into viral capsids at a rate of up to 2000 base pairs per second (bp/s), and it is extremely powerful.
t4.What determines the final step of the T4: The final step of the T4 replication cycle is determined by the release of virions from the host cell. This occurs after the breakage of the plasma membrane.
t4.How do nonenveloped viruses like T4 typi: Nonenveloped viruses like T4 typically lyse the host cell. Their mode of release is characterized by viral proteins attacking peptidoglycan (PG) and the cell membrane. Lysis occurs when capsids release lysozyme that breaks down the cell wall.
t4.What happens after the release of phages: After the release of phages from the host cell, they infect other cells, and the replication cycle continues.
t4.What is Multiplicity Reactivation (MR)?: MR is the process by which 2 or more genomes, each containing inactivating genome damage, can interact with an infected cell to form a viable virus genome.
t4.Who discovered Multiplicity Reactivation: Salvador Luria discovered MR in 1946 while studying UV irradiated T4 phages.
t4.What is the significance of Multiplicity: The discovery of MR preceded the confirmation of DNA as the genetic material in 1952 (by Hershey and Chase) and initiated the study of repair of radiation damage within the early phage group.
t4.What did the discovery of Multiplicity R: It led to the understanding that the repair of damaged virus by mutual help was common throughout every single type of cell, not just for phages or bacteria. Additionally, it highlighted the critical role of DNA repair processes in protecting against aging, cancer, and infertility.
t4.How is Multiplicity Reactivation observe: MR is represented as survival curves where the survival of plaque forming ability of multiple infected cells (multicomplexes) is plotted against the dose of the genome damaging agent. Monocomplexes (single cells) are also plotted against the dose of the genome damaging agent.
t4.What are some examples of agents exhibit: Agents such as UV irradiation, X-rays, and ethyl methane sulfonate show shoulders in survival curves of multicomplexes, indicating Multiplicity Reactivation.
t4.What does the presence of a shoulder in: The presence of a shoulder in survival curves indicates the utilization of two recombinational processes.
t4.How many recombinational processes are i: When a shoulder is present in survival curves, it indicates the utilization of two recombinational processes.
t4.What is indicated by the efficiency of r: The efficiency of repair is indicated by the fact that a dose of mitomycin C allowing survival of only 1/1000 monocomplexes permits the survival of 70% of multicomplexes.
t4.Which agents produce nonshouldered multi: Nonshouldered multicomplex survival curves are observed with damaging agents such as P32 decay, psoralen+UV irradiation (PUVA), N-methyl-N’-nitro-N-nitrosoguanidine (MNNG), methyl methane sulfonate (MMS), and nitrous acid.
t4.What genes are necessary for multiplicit: Several genes necessary for multiplicity reactivation in T4 are proved to be orthologs of genes necessary for recombination in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
t4.What role does the T4 gene uvsX play?: The T4 gene uvsX specifies a protein with 3D structural homology to RecA in E. coli, RAD51 in eukaryotes, and RadA in archaea. It is involved in efficient and accurate recombinational repair of DNA damage during multiplicity reactivation, potentially analogous to recombinational repair during meiosis in eukaryotes.
